speaker: Mr Harry Woods (Page) (10.01 A.m.)
theText: Let me first take exception to the assertion byMC 1628 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 capital. Casino, in my electorate, is widely recognised as the beef capital, and I would hope to have some support from the National Party in that respect. There are a few things certain in life and amongst those is that the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard), when he gets up and speaks, will offer no policy ideas. Another, of course, is that whenever the member for Gwydir, the Deputy Leader of the National Party, speaks on the meat industry, he invariably takes the tack of kicking the unions, of running the meat industry down and of being a prophet of doom. His evidence yesterday to show that this gloom was justified was that an Australian firm had thought about importing 15 container loads of meat. That is very flimsy evidence, because Australia is a major exporter of beef, a major player in world terms in Japan, in Korea and in the United States. It is a $5 billion industry and we do it extremely well. That is not to say, of course, that there cannot be improvements in efficiency, and one of those areas that does need attention is the industrial relations side. But this will never be achieved by simply kicking the industry, kicking the workers in the industry and telling them that they are no good. It wilLbe achieved through good, solid legislation such as this that moves things forward. This legislation represents a major step forwa,rd for the meat and livestock indu-try by providing commitment to the industry'S workplace agreements through the establishment of a meat industry council. It will give the industry a greater role in responsibility in deciding its own affairs, and that must inevitably result in greater productivity and efficiency from a less regulated environment. The meat and livestock industry is one that Australia depends on for much of its primary industry revenue. We owe it to the industry and also to all Australians to prove that we want a strong and efficient industry, an industry that can reach its potential. But at the same time we want to provide a sound framework so that we can continue in a way that will allow flexibility and reform and a firm commitment to secure more employment for future Australians. The establishment of a meat industry council is the most appropriate way to develop strategic policy and planning and to address the meat industry's costs and competitiveness issues. The Meat Industry Council will take the responsibility for strategic planning and then provide the framework for the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Meat Research Corporation to develop their corporate and operational plans. The Meat Industry Council will also be responsible for the funding of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Meat Research Corporation through the power to recommend levy rates to industry annual general meetings. The MIC's new component will reflect the expenditure on functions that the MIC is taking over from the AMLC and the MRC. Therefore, it will not add to the total levy and charge collected. I want to stress that the new arrangements are not expected to impose any additional costs on the Commonwealth and, more importantly, any additional costs on the industry at this time. The Commonwealth will also continue to make matching payments for research and development expenditure from the meat research and development fund up to a maximum of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of meat and livestock, as determined by the minister. These provisions ensure that programs of the AMLC and the MRC conform with the industry's strategic goals, directed through the MIC. The legislation gives the meat industry a greater role and responsibility in deciding its own affairs and the ability to move to a less Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1629 regulated environment. Although it is transitional and eventually the three statutory industry authorities will revert to a non-statutory status, a framework will be established where the industry can operate over the longer term. It is of utmost importance to the meat and livestock industry that. a meat industry council be established as a part of the whole decentralisation process. The ultimate aim of this legislation is to improve efficiency whilst maintaining a strong body to direct and focus the industry's strategic direction through the AMLC and the MRC. It is only logical that a body which is already familiar with the problems associated with the meat industry be established so it can form realistic goals and, through an efficient and streamlined process, address problems that are inherent in the meat industry. The MIC will ensure that the industry is able to identify its problems and, consequently, provide it with the framework to enable commercial responses to be formulated to combat difficulties. Ultimately, this will take the financial responsibility offthe shoulders of the producer and take it out into the national realm. This will encourage easier access to greater competition and, inevitably, a more cost-effective industry. The meat industry is very important to my electorate of Page .. We recently celebrated Beef Week in Casino, which is in my electorate. Casino, which is recognised as the beef capital of Australia, as I said earlier, relies heavily on the beef industry. Beef Week in Casino actually goes for about 12 days. It is a nationaL promotion for the beef industry, an industry which is a major source of employment, not just in Casino but throughout the north coast. There has been a feeling of impotence within the industry because of its inability to control its own destiny and because of a perception that many issues are not addressed on a strategic and continuing policy development basis. '. The Northern Cooperative Meatworks Company is also in the electorate of Page. That company recently celebrated a centenary of productivity. It is one of the largest exporters of meat in Australia, and it is certainly the largest single employer of workers in my electorate. The formation of the Meat Industry Council will certainly benefit both the cooperative and its workers. The issue of industrial relations in this area has not been addressed as efficiently as it should have been. This legislation highlights the need for industrial relations reform in the meat industry. Improved industrial relations will increase the productivity and the efficiency of the meat processing sector, as the inquiries undertaken by the Meat Industry Commission in 1994 and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in 1992 suggested. However, a recent report commissioned by the Department of Industrial Relations found that, despite efforts by some employers and union ·officials, the majority of the meat industry work force was still distrustful of change; We must overcome the preconceived idea that industrial relations is a big stick wielded by the government to bring industry into line. The establishment of the Meat Industry Council will allow for autonomy and a state of binary opposition that will promote flexibility and cost efficiency and, whilst maintaining national unity, will provide a strategy and a framework to work in. In March 1995, a report commissioned by the Department of Industrial Relations on the progress of workplace reform in the export meat processing industry indicated that poor relationships between the parties in the meat industry are a major impediment to workplace reform. This legislation aims to overcome those shortcomings in the industry by restructuring it and giving it teeth. Importantly, the proposed MIC has the clear responsibility for MC 1630 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 formulating industry policy as well as evaluating industry programs against performance criteria. This is a crucial responsibility of the MIC if it is to work. One way in which a major improvement is suggested is through the increase in enterprise bargaining agreements. In the industrial relations report of March 1995, the finding included that progress with enterprise bargaining was limited, that the agreements had not been innovative, and that not enough had. been contributed to the lifting of productivity and efficiency. The Meat Industry Council will bring together representatives of the producers, processors and the union to formulate the best approach that will lead the meat industry into a productive and guaranteed future. An interim council has already identified industry costs as a priority issue. What we need is a framework in place that will benefit the workers of companies like the Northern Cooperative Meatworks Company and other meat works throughout Australia. We need a framework that will allow workers, employers and unions to come together to discuss how they can coristructively tackle the problems that are in the industry and in which they have a vested interest. The MIC will allow that to OCCllr. At a recent interim MIC meeting, the council has already agreed to a study being undertaken by the Meat Research Corporation on the comparative structure and performance of sectors of the industry to assist the council in formulating strategies to raise its performance. We should not underestimate the ability of the industry to manage its own affairs. Industry leaders are running a large, $5 billion plus industry and making difficult and successful commercial decisions every day. If industry is not in charge of its own" affairs, it is legitimately able to deflect blame forbad decisions to others and thus avoid the difficult decisions. Industry has sought responsibility for its own affairs. The government is confident that industry is capable of managing its own affairs and taking the industry forward to meet the challenges of the 21st century. The deregulatory approach is staged to allow industry professionalism to develop. If this does not evolve as expected, the government will not walk away from this very important industry. Further reform options would then be considered in conjunction with industry. In the case of the ALMC, where industry funding only is involved, the MIC will examine programs which can be commercialised and develop strategic plans to pursue this. CALM and Aus-Meat programs are expected to be the first to be examined. Other programs might include market intelligence and reporting. The scope for export promotion and marketing being commercialised will also be considered by the MIC, in the context of the branding of product to minimise market failure. It may take some time for industry to commercialise marketing and promotion, given the generic nutritional and health issues involved and the activities of competitor meats. The MRC is currently examining the scope for it to commercialise R&D, drawing on overseas experience, and this will be progressed under the guidance of the new MIC. It envisages, however, matched government funding continuing. It is reasonable to look forward, with some of the GATT outcomes and some of the progress-admittedly not enough-in the meat industry. The meat industry as it is now is a powerful and strong player not only in the Australian economy but in exports overseas, and I think it is reasonable to be optimistic about a good future where there is enormous potential for our meat industry and export markets. With the people involved and the leadership given, we can look forward to that potential and those opportunities being taken up in coming years . . REPRESENTATIVES MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1631 This legislation builds on a framework designed to create a strong and efficient meat industry, able to take up the opportunities that will present themselves in the future, and to maximise its potential. I urge honourable members to support it. for Bendigo( Mr Reid) I think I should clarify the question that is before the Main Committee. The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable the Deputy Leader of the National Party has moved, as an amendment, that all words after 'that' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. Therefore, the immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question. livestock industry legislation provides an opportunity to talk about the marketing and sale of livestock in Australia. Much discussion has occurred in recent times on the selling methods available to producers for the sale of their livestock to domestic and overseas markets. One thing is for certain-that farmers want a fair and adequate return for their stock, which can be achieved where true market forces operate in a competitive environment. This can be achieved in a number of different ways and there is no doubt that saleyards will continue into the future in Victoria and throughout Australia. New selling methods, both on farm and off, certainly have a place, as do the new technology sales using video facilities. However, it is generally agreed throughout the industries that saleyards will remain the primary method of selling stock through a competitive bidding system in the long-term future. The issue, therefore, is which saleyards will grow and which saleyards will diminish and eventually close. The area that I represent, Bendigo, has the largest or equal largest sheep and lamb saleyard in Victoria and it will continue to play this role in a long-term future. The Bendigo saleyards recently opened a new on-scale selling facility for cattle, and that will help the city of greater Bendigo and the farmers in that area move with modem trends. There are a number of smaller saleyards in Victoria which are unlikely to survive into the future. However, it would be inappropriate for me to speculate on which these may be. The city of greater Bendigo is committed to maintaining a major saleyards operation in Bendigo. It is presently looking at a relocation of the saleyards which will ensure that Bendigo continues as the largest, or equal largest, sheep saleyards in Victoria. It will be also doing significant work to ensure that cattle, pig and, possibly, other sales will grow significantly. Saleyards throughout Australia, and particularly in Victoria, have a good future. While we acknowledge the existence of other forms of selling, saleyards will still be the predominant form of livestock selling in Victoria for the foreseeable future. I want to quote some figures in relation to the throughput of the saleyards in the Bendigo area, and then relate that back to the stock figures of sales in Victoria. At the city of greater Bendigo saleyards in 1993-94, the yardage figures relate to the various stock categories for th-t year, and they are: sheep, 875,980; cattle, 37,493; pigs, 30,380; and calves, 1,725. The figures from the saleyards of Victoria, where there are some 30 saleyards-there are smaller ones, but they do not keep reliable stock figures-show that, in the same year of 1993-94, Victoria had a total stock throughput in these categories: sheep, 4,950,891; cattle, 1,265,687; pigs, 59,010; and calves, 82,602. Some of those numbers have been down through those years; but, once the impact of the drought through northern central Victoria is removed, I am sure those numbers will increase once again. speaker: Mr Reid (Bendigo) (10.14 A.m.)
theText: The cognate debate this morning on the meat andMC 1632 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 number of reasons, one being the drought; but there certainly has been a decline, and there may have been lost opportunities in the livestock marketing and selling area. I want to talk about the economic benefits that a saleyard can bring to an area. I refer to a document prepared by Crichton Maxwell Pty Ltd in May 1995, so it is absolutely current. That firm was asked by the city of greater Bendigo to evaluate what the economics of saleyards did to the economic region. It came up with an appraisal of what the economic benefits. of livestock selling would be for an area, and it particularly directed its attention to the city of greater Bendigo saleyards. It found that the total employment generated by the saleyards is conservatively calculated at 317 people, with an overall annual economic value to the City of greater Bendigo in 1995 of some $18.45 million. There would be few industries in the city of greater Bendigo that could match that result in terms of employment and economic value generation. The employment figures are made up in several different ways. Firstly, the figures for direct employment generated by the city of greater Bendigo saleyards and those employer categories are: stock agents, 40; transport operators, 30; city of greater Bendigo personnel,5; making a total direct employment of 75. Then there are all the indirect employment categories which support· the City of greater Bendigo saleyards including truck serviCing, engineering firms, shearers, tyre suppliers, the water supply authority, fuel companies, stock and station firms, cat retailers, and transport operators . .That also flows on to other areas of activity such as the retail sector in the city of greater Bendigo. The latest estimate of retail turnover in the City of greater Bendigo, taken out in 1993, was $442 million. That figure has been transferred to an employment generating figure as a result of direct saleyards activity. The saleyards directly employ 75, as I indicated; saleyards agricultural indirectly employs 112; the retail sector directly employs 52; and the retail sector dependent employs 78-totalling employment of 317 people. Honourable members can see that the saleyards are a very strong economic stimulus and a very strong livestock selling centre bringing direct economic benefit to the whole community. The direct cash flow generated by the City of greater Bendigo saleyards includes: stock agents' commissions, approximately $2.15 million; yardage fees, approximately $0.5 million; and transport charges, approximately $3.7 million. Some 80 per cent or $2.96 million flows directly to the region and the remainder goes to other regions, making a direct cash flow generated by the City of greater Bendigo saleyards of $5.61 million. Bearing in mind the economic stimulus that saleyards create and the importance of the livestock industry to the city of Greater Bendigo, one would have to wonder why in 1985 the two Labor members representing the area-the former federal member for Bendigo, Mr Brumby, and the former Labor member for Bendigo West in the Victorian Legislative Assembly, Mr David Kennedy-rejected government assistance of over $1 million to provide upgrading and relocation of the livestock selling centre in Bendigo. That money was to be available in 1985 under an employment (;reation grant. Regrettably, that allocation was not taken up. That was the opportune time to relocate because there had been a decline in numbers and it was an appropriate time to introduce all the new technologies that the saleyards could produce. Modem technology was evolving using a range of video facilities for on-farm and off-farm selling of livestock through saleyards. However, as a result of the reluctance of these two members to take up the additional funding that could have been made available, Bendigo lost the opportunity. Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1633 The proposal to relocate the saleyards has been accepted by the rural community. A great deal of consultation has been achieved by the city of greater Bendigo. Discussions included a range of people, including stock and station agents, stock and station managers, farmers, stock buyers, stock traders, transport operators, Bendigo business houses, Department of Agriculture staff, and agricultural economists. These people were of the view that saleyards would play an important part in the marketing and selling of livestock into the future .. The summary presented by Crichton Maxwell Pty Ltd says: The COGB saleyards are seen within the livestock industry to be one of Australia's premier selling centres, even though outdated facilities are used. Crichton Maxwell Pty Ltd refers to the fact that an opportunity existed in 1985 to upgrade and to relocate the facilities, but that the opportunity was not taken up. Stocks sold through the saleyards are drawn from a large proportion of Victoria and. also from New South Wales. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, directly to the north of my electorate is a large dairying industry and there is also production of fat cattle. Had the saleyards been upgraded and new technology introduced back in 1985, greater impetus and a higher yardage of cattle from the area would have been attracted. The saleyards are a substantial generator of both direct and indirect employment, creating some 317 jobs directly and indirectly. Of course, economic benefits flow as a res.ult of saleyards operating in that location: farmers come in and out of the district; agents come from all over Australia; and buyers come from all over the world to purchase livestock. The saleyards provide a very strong economic stimulus to the Bendigo region. The total employment generated is 317, with an overall economic value to the city of greater Bendigo of $18.45 million. The summary presented by Crichton Maxwell Pty Ltd states: The objective in relocating the COGB saleyards, should be to establish a Regional and Victorian Agricultural Centre that is the focus for a 200km radius, based on Bendigo, but also for a large part of south western NSW. Able to provide all first level demands and if unable to provide them all, the remainder being sourced or accessed out of COGB CBD. The farming community wants the opportunity to present stock to buyers in the best possible condition. Farmers want a fair and adequate return for the livestock that they are marketing and they want that return to be achieved in a competitive environment where true market forces operate. Whether attempts are made to sell stock at saleyards or out on a farm, the farming community is looking for a fair and adequate return for its efforts when stock is presented to the market in the best condition possible. Looking at the future of saleyards, obviously the numbers of saleyards throughout Australia will diminish somewhat because of the introduction of new methods. The city of greater Bendigo is taking important steps to ensure that the area in which it is located is the leader in the sale of livestock. The city of greater Bendigo wants to ensure that the conditions presented to farmers and to buyers are the best that are available so as to ensure that the area holds its place in the very important function of the sale of livestock in Victoria and throughout Australia. One of the low points for Bendigo is the loss of an abattoir which was located in the Bendigo area. The abattoir was operated by the Victorian Inland Meat Authority. When the abattoir was sold, ownership was transferred to a number of owners and it ultimately ended up as a part of the Mayfair group. At one time, there was an industrial dispute at the abattoirs. The industrial dispute was being resolved at a local level until Mr Wally Curran, Secretary MC 1634 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 of the Australasian Meatworkers Union, pulled the workers out on strike. Mr Curran kept them out on strike and then he departed for an eight-week holiday overseas. Regrettably, the meat works did not ever recover from the strike. Bendigo lost the abattoirs· and 600 people lost their jobs. Bendigo never recovered from that. It is an important adjunct to have a meat processing works which can use the livestock selling centre of Bendigo in providing a service to it and in providing both domestic and overseas killing facilities, so that the livestock can actually be processed in the area where the saleyards operate. That situation was to the detriment of Bendigo and it has had an impact on it. The city of greater Bendigo has picked up the challenge of providing better facilities for the rural community and for the buyers in this most important industry, the meat and livestock industry. I have expressed the wish of the rural community to have these facilities upgraded, relocated and providing the absolute best conditions available for the rural community to achieve a fair and adequate price for their livestock. bills form part of a package of legislation to reform the meat and livestock industry statutory arrangements. The purpose of the Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill 1995 and associated bills is to provide the framework which will constitute the future of the industry. This jsnecessary as a result of the changes within the industry. As the meat and livestock industry moves towards the next decade, it is necessary to provide it with much greater responsibility for its own affairs. This will enable it to be more competitive and more flexible in responding to future consumer challenges. My electorate of Leichhardt represents an economically diverse region. Major expansion in the tourism industry has radically altered the economic base. Its origins, however, are those of a regional centre and the local economy is still based on that core. As the Minister for Resources ( Mr Beddall) said in his second reading speech, this legislation is necessary to assist industry to move towards its goal of becoming more internationally competitive and better able to respond to the more exacting consumer requirements throughout the world. That is what this legislation is about. This could not be more 'true than for the Far North Queensland beef industry. The beef industry in Far North Queensland-as well as its horticultural, aquacultural and agricultural industries-has great potential to export to the South-East Asian and South Pacific markets through the seaports of Cairns and Karumba and through Cairns international airport. These markets are becoming more and more sophisticated in many ways. Clean food and clean environment are major selling points for Australia, and we should not forget that. This legislation will assist in the value adding of meat produced in Australia. The legislation allows the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, in cooperation with other organisations, to facilitate the marketing of goods other than meat and livestock. The AMLC's legislation will also be extended to cover by-products of the meat and livestock industry. This is a power which the Meat Research Corporation already has under existing legislation. The Meat Industry Council will have the responsibility to develop a strategy for adding value to the by-products and co-products area. As the Minister for Resources said in his second reading speech, there is considerable scope for further improvement in this area. theText: The Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill and associatedThursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1635 is obviously also true to a great extent for some other parts of the Australian market-the Far North Queensland meat industry has an excellent opportunity to develop new markets. I was very pleased, very recently, to have the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) visit my electorate to launch the Australia wide business industry networks. They provide not only the opportunity but also government assistance to help small businesses to develop export markets, in particular to South-East Asia and the South Pacific. This is important because small firms have not got either the time or the expertise to develop their own infrastructure in relation to exporting. These industry networks provide a means for that to come about. It was very interesting, and I use that word very loosely, to hear the speech that was given yesterday by the honourable member for Gwydir( Mr Anderson), who, as I understand it, is the shadow minister for primary industry. theText: As seconder of the amendment moved by the memberThursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1637 delegation led by Senator Michael Beahan. It was an all-party delegation which attacked this in a bipartisan fashion, and that is the way it should be. I was privileged to be in the delegation. BecauseI was a National Party member and very conversant with things rural, I was able to be the major spokesman and the focus of the representations being made to the Americans on the needs of Australian primary producers. It is particularly important to realise that the American farm bill is American domestic policy. This is one of the things that I and other members of the delegation said on every opportunity. We said to people-and I actually said this to Vice-President Gore-'We realise this is your domestic policy. It is none of our business, except that you have to realise that if you cough, we get influenza.' That is true. We were also very concerned about the impact of what the Americans have done with their export enhancement program, EEP. The most senior person we spoke with was the Vice-President, which is almost as high as you can get. After that we met Pat Roberts, who was the chairman of the House agriculture committee. Senator Richard Lugar was very involved in his preparations for announcing his candidacy for the presidency, and we were not able to see him, but we also had very useful talks with other officials in Washington such as the Library of Congress research people involved in the formulation of the policy. Australia's primary producers should be aware that there is not going to be an easy answer to this. There are basically two farm bills coming through. One is from the Senate, sponsored by Senator Lugar, and he is making a much stronger move and seeking to have the subsidies reduced significantly. The one coming through from the House takes a much softer approach, and is more concerned with maintaining the subsidies. Everywhere that we went throughout the United States on the rest of the delegation, we told people that we had been talking in Washington about this on behalf of Australia's primary producers, and all the Americans said, 'What's going to happen?' Nobody knows. The reality will probably be that the subsidies will be reduced to some extent. We should realise that it is not just EEP. There is a whole range of ways American primary producers are subsidisedlike the food stamps program, which is bound up with welfare as well-so it is very important that we understand what is happening there. The reality is that the Americans do have to reduce their deficit. Theirs is on the same scale as the deficit of this government. Let us, while we are at it, realise that that deficit is not a surplus of $700-odd million. What a confection! What a farce! What fairy floss from the show! The real deficit is at least $8 billion. The New South Wales farmers have recently published a journal which quotes from Bain and Co. and shows that the real, fair dinkum deficit is probably over $12 billion. That is going to impact severely on Australia's primary producers. While I have the floor, Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to make a point about the primary producers in my electorate of Cowper. I note what the member for Bendigo( Mr Reid), the member for Page( Mr Harry Woods) and the member for Leichhardt have been saying about their particular areas. The north coast of New South Wales is the major cattle breeding area for the whole of New South Wales. In fact, 70 per cent of the cattle bred in New South Wales are bred on the north coast. It is a particularly important industry for the north coast of New South Wales. We have major saleyards at Kempsey which handle a lot of cattle. Again, at Macksville there are excellent saleyards, and the major abattoir that we have is Midco at Macksville. I have to give full praise to the management and workers of Midco. They do a tremendous job, and produce great exports for Australia. MC 1638 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 sanctimonious interventions. I ask that he desist. The member for Cowper has the floor. Unfortunately, they fell upon hard times some years ago. When I was first elected in 1984 they were in a situation where a receiver had been appointed. They were in great trouble, so much so that one of the first things I did on being elected to this parliament was to have the Parliamentary Library prepare a special research paper on the economic impact on the Nambucca Valley, should that meat works close. That is how close it was. I know there are differing views about importing capital, and particularly about the impact of Japanese investment in Australia. But I must say that, since the Midco meat works at Macksville was purchased by the Japanese firm Mitsubishi, that meat works has gone from strength to strength. It has had its ups and downs but, by and large, it has been the iron lung of the Nambucca Valley and also, of course, beyond. People from places such as Stuarts Point and Bellingen actually work there. There are hundreds of employees. Over the last 10 years, I do not know how many millions of dollars Mitsubishihas invested, but it has made major investments, sometimes of $20 million in one whack. To go through that works and see the men at work is a great pleasure. The equipment and the lines are state of the art: all stainless steel. The efficiency of those fellows, as you see them working on the beast, is ajoy to behold. They are really great people. The primary producers are well served by that abattoir. There is also another small one, the Everson one at Frederickton in the McLeay Valley, which also does a very good job, though on a much smaller scale. In conclusion, the meat industry and the primary producers of Australia are of vital importance. Whilst some people tend to denigrate the value of primary production, it is still the mainstay of Australia's exports: one should have no doubt about that. I take this opportunity-to use the favourite phrase of my leader, the honourable member for Farrer( Mr Fischer)-to salute the primary producers, the workers and the meat processors of Australia. speaker: Ms Henzell
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, when I heard your predecessor in the chair suddenlyThursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1639 misunderstanding or mischievous analysis of what I said in the House. HadI had his press release at the time, I would have referred to him specifically in my explanation to the House a few weeks ago. But I will pass over that matter, because the member for Gwydir, the opposition spokesperson, did raise some criticisms of this bill. Firstly, he criticised the fact that it was actually being debated in this chamber, a criticism which I thought was irrelevant. He indicated that the opposition would, in general, support this bill with a second reading amendment. We should remind ourselves that the Cattle Council of Australia and all the peak bodies involved in the meat industry in this country are supporting this legislation and these recommendations. The member for Gwydir criticised the lack in the bill of any procedures to implement the Industry Commission report. From the report, he quoted the first couple of paragraphs of the overview. Indeed, he quoted from the very first paragraph. We have to be very careful of selective quoting; and, while I do not deny that what the member quoted was exactly what the report says, let me read from the end of the overview about the effects of the Industry Commission's recommendations. In part, the conclusions of the overview read: The Commission's recommendations build on reforms which have been initiated over the last decade. They have been made with a view to facilitating the transition from a commodity based, adversarial industry with low levels of skills towards a modem, collaborative and productive industry. In particular, they are designed to: increase the level of skill in the workplace, the flexibility with which it is deployed and the level of workplace health and safety; assist the process of achieving greater market access for Australian meat and meat products; increase commercial incentives for firms to conduct their own research, development and market promotion . . . That is, they have been designed to take government off the back of the industry. The Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) has indicated that he wants to take government off the backs of the people. In this bill, the government has provided for the industry to take control of its destiny, to take control of its own procedures and to make itself more competitive and outward looking. Yet all we get is carping criticism from the opposition and a pretty fair wallop of union bashing from the opposition spokesperson, the member for Gwydir, yesterday. But I digress from the effects of the recommendations of the Industry Commission, which continue: ... increase the extent to which the industry, whether on its own or in collaboration with government, is able to adopt a means of ensuring the hygiene and safety of its output at least costobviously a key issue for exportersincrease the capacity of producers and processors to receive feedback on how they can each meet each other's needs; reduce the level of direct public sector involvement in the industry; and facilitate measures to reduce costs and increase productivity in all sectors of the industry. These are commendable recommendations. The matters in the bill, involving the restructuring of the industry, are designed to produce those results. The other issue that we have to be very careful about is to make sure that all parties in the industry are involved, including producers. For too long, there has been a tendency, particularly among members of the opposition, to say, 'It is the meat processors, in particular the meat workers, who cause all the problems.' The member for Gwydir referred to the Booz Allen and Hamilton report for the Cattle Council of Australia, International comparisons in the beef processing industry, which is an excellent document. His aim in referring to this was to show how uncompetitive the Australian beef industry is. MC 1640 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 One of the important points made on page 35 of this review is that up to 70 per cent of the processing gap-defined in the report as $198.49 a head-is beyond the control of processors; but that around 30 per cent is addressable. It is very important to know this. All sectors of the industry, particularly the processing end, are willing to address that issue. The report does make international comparisons, but it is misleading for the member for Gwydir to mention figures from industries in countries such as Argentina and America, when the report itself clearly makes the point that only 30 per cent of this is to do with the processing industry. This is hardly the point made by the opposition spokesperson and comes from a report initiated by the Cattle Council of Australia. The other report that the member for Gwydir used was the report made by Fellows Medlock and Associates, dated March 1995. This was a report to the Minister for Industrial Relations ( Mr Brereton) entitled Review of progress in workplace reform in the export meat processing sector. I am delighted that the opposition spokesperson referred to this, but once again he quoted rather selectively to suggest that all the problems in the meat processing industry were the fault of the unions. I believe that this is unhelpful to the debate and I will refer to aspects of the report to clarify the position. It will be instructive to all members. Under the heading 'Difficulties or impediments to enterprise bargaining' the document states: ... a number of evident impediments to enterprise bargaining are dealt with throughout the report and are summarised below. The major impediment lies in the attitudes of the industry's employers, union officials and employees. Whilst employers and unions have expressed positive views about the need to change, this has to a large extent not been reflected in action. That this has not occurred illustrates the poor relationships which exist in the industry with trust and goodwill clearly lacking. Where co-operative relationships have been established, it is possible to point to progress in improving productivity at plant level. . The key issue for this industry is making a difference to that cost gap of 30 per cent, but it will require changes to the culture of the workplace: changes in the attitudes of management, of unions and of the work force, and not only at the national leVel but also on a plant-by-plant basis. There is evidence that, where the culture of the workplace is an issue and there is a need to educate and train employees and take them through the process, you can actually achieve very positive results. The other issue that I think is important is this: what are the impediments to change? This is referred to on page 5 of the report. Impediments to change identified by this report included the following: a) Employers: with some exceptions, the industry'S individual employers generally display a traditional and nartow approach to relations with their employees and unions and have failed to acknowledge change where it has occurred. The concept of Best Practice is not well understood by the industry's employers who have generally looked for excuses rather than accept that the initiative for reform must lie with management. And the report is critical of the union and the work force. In the industry, there is a clear lack of unity and common purpose among all participants. Failure to support the central role for the Australian Industrial Relations Commi-sion and the absence of a respected and visionary employer association are major impediments to reform. I make these points to indicate that there have been initiatives on all sides, from the processing end, from the producer end and from the government end. Indeed, our reforms have reflected that change. However, we are talking about a very conservative industry on both sides, an industry where there has been a tendency to use very out-of-date industrial relations Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1641 mechanisms on both sides but where there is a preparedness and a willingness to change. However, that has to be capitalised on. The conclusions in the overview state: Despite the on-going debate about the relative significance of workplace refonn in the overall competitiveness of the industry, there is a broad agreement among the various parties that refonn will improve perfonnance at an individual and company level. However, before sustained improvements can be achieved, it is essential that a clear, consistent and supportive message is delivered at the workplace by both employers and unions. From the views expressed during the course of this review, it is evident that sufficient commonality exists for the parties to develop a shared agenda as the basis of a commitment to a widespread education process about the need for, and benefits of, workplace refonn. The challenge for all the parties involved will be to translate their support for refonn into a concrete action plan for change at the individual company level. That is the challenge for this industry and the one that all of us should be supporting. Having gone through a very effective consultation process with all players in the industry, the Industry Commission, on page 29 of its report, concludes: All parties expressed scepticism about any ability to achieve refonn at the industry level. There is no body, at this stage, which has sufficient respect or support to be able to playa role in bringing the parties together to foster refonn. While refonn must be focused at the individual plant level, an industry-wide vision for change, supported by agreed principles and a broad action plan could play an essential role in educating the parties and facilitating enterprise level refonn. It is certainly the case that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is one party to that reform but, if management and unions think that is the only way to do this, we will not achieve a great deal. The unions have shown a preparedness to be very flexible but, at the same time, that must be based on some degree of trust and confidence so that, where agreements are developed, employers will follow through on their promises. There is no doubt that educating the workplace, which is as much a challenge to the unions as it is to the employers, is going to be very important in this process. I want to give a classic example of this issue in my electorate of Rockhampton, where Australia Meat Holdings is at present in dispute with the AMIEU. I have had discussions with some representatives of AMH. I have discussed with them the sorts of initiatives the company has put into its operation at Guyra, which I dare say the opposition spokesperson must know about because it is in his electorate. He did not mention it yesterday. I think that at one level AMH is keen to adopt productive processes whereby it can initiate the sort of changes that are needed to improve capital utilisation. I have not had a chance to talk to the employees as Guyra but I know the union has some concerns about the way the process was developed. In the Country Life of 1 June, the AMH chairman, Keith Lawson, is reported as follows: "Enterprise bargaining does offer the industry real hope. It will have significant ramifications and it is important that producers understand that refonn has been resisted and is therefore slow," Mr Lawson said. "But we are committed to getting it right. It is our only hope of survival against international competitors. " The problem is that at the bottom end of this kind of process we have got a situation at AMH Fitzroy Abattoirs, in my electorate, where the employees, having gone through a long process of trying to develop an enterprise agreement and working under an industrial award from the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission, became so frustrated that they walked off the job one Friday afternoon. They did not follow the disputes resolution procedure technically, but they were prepared to come back on the Monday and to re-initiate the process if they could get some commitment from AMH to follow through on the promises that had been made. What MC 1642 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 followed was essentially a lock-out of the work force, with public pronouncements by the industrial relations spokesperson to the effect that the company was simply going to re-hire anybody who would come-precipitating a strikebreaking operation. The union, in attempting to get a resolution according to the agreed-upon disputes resolution, spent considerable time attempting to get some agreement with the AMH representative and in the end had to go back to the Industrial Relations Commission. That will be heard tomorrow in Brisbane. At the same time, I understand, AMH was in the Industrial Relations Commission because it is in conflict with MATFA over whether or not it should be a signatory to the industry-wide award. While I understand the frustration and concern of AMH, the way it has gone about attempting to resolve this dispute will not forward an effective, productive enterprise bargaining agreement. The work force believes that the management will re-employ a number of the workers but pick off the workers that it does not want. The resolution yesterday at the picket line was that all workers would re-apply for their jobs but the union expected all its members to be re-employed, so that the enterprise negotiation would go ahead. In fact, the union officials obtained a commitment from the work force that workers would not stage any sort of walkout unless it was sanctioned by a state official. The union officials in this situation have worked very hard to forward the process of enterprise bargaining, but feel a great lack of confidence in the position of management. It is this kind of industrial dispute that, in my view, will put back enterprise bargaining for years in Rockhampton. It is an industry that is absolutely essential to the economy of Rockhampton. We have had the Smorgons Lakes Creek meat works closed all year, because Smorgons decided to divest itself of its entire company structure. company's meat processing industry but the whole thing. In the meantime, the company did not give two hoots about what happened to the workers and their families in Rockhampton. It held out and held out in terms of paying the redundancy payments that were due to those workers-workers who have to suffer seasonal working arrangements and hiring and firing on a daily basis. Basically, people in this place should know that we are talking about an industry that goes back a long way. It is a piece of industrial archaeology, to quote the Prime Minister( Mr Keating). It is not conducive to getting good performance out of any employee. perhaps take a different view of how it should be done. At the end of the day I urge, and I have done so, the people from AMH to sit down and start negotiating a way through this mess. They need to provide education and skill formation, and they need to do something constructive about bringing their work force with them. AMH may well decide that it can just pull the pin and move its operations but that will not help the beef producers of Central Queensland. At the moment, because our two meat works are closed, our cattle producers are having to freight their stock to Brisbane. The cost involved in that is huge. I was at a meeting at Claremont where the AMH representative was having a crack at workers by saying, 'It's all the fault of the work force.' The producers were saying, 'Yes, that is true.' theText: I think if any member here worked inside this industry, they wouldThursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1643 beef producers: cattlemen and women work hard to put up prime beef for sale only to get the lowest price possible. There is a great need, at all levels of this industry, for men and women of goodwill to sit down and work out how best they can forward this industry which is so vital to Australia's future. I urge all players in this industry to do that, including the opposition. I would like to know the opposition's policy on this issue. All we hear from the opposition is criticism, in spite of the support of all of the peak bodies to this legislation. The government is once again delivering on reform. It is about getting the government off the back of the industry and about asking the industry to take responsibility for its processes, to become competitive, to get niche markets and to make sure of the product that it is producing. One of our problems is that we do not grain feed a lot of our beef. We still use open range and that makes us less competitive. There are a number of issues involved here. It is not just the poor old meatworker. appreciation to the House for the circumstances we found ourselves in a few moments ago and convey my apologies to you. the former Deputy Speaker, who was most accommodating at that point. that other members have outlined but to the exotic animal disease aspect of this legislation. It has concerned me for some time that there is a change in the ethos in assessing the vulnerability of Australia to the imported exotic diseases. It may be a fairly roundabout process but I ask the House to bear with me as we trace the change in the processes used by the government, and the animal quarantine and export branch of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. I think we can find part of the answer there that we need to have if we are going to build a safe and secure animal production industry in Australia. Safe and secure animal production for Australia is critical. Not only must we have an input into research and development, and the latest techniques of production, but we must be safeguarding our great industries as well. I wish to take the House back to the notorious case of the import of pig meat, take that as a case example, look at poultry production and draw from that some conclusions as to what might be proper practices and policies for this nation in the future. As far back as 1988, there were circulars from the Department of Primary. Industries and Energy with regard to pig reproduction centres and pig import conditions. Those circulars laid out some of the criteria that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy sought to impose upon those people producing pig meat in international circumstances and the conditions of quarantine that would apply should Australia consider the import of pig meat. At that time, there was great activity in the pig and poultry industries, as growers and producers tried to assess what, for them, was an innovation-the idea that Australia should actually be an importer of these fragile primary products, which notoriously could present a risk for Australian producers should exotic diseases gain entry into Australia in any way. At that time, I wrote to the then minister for resources, the honourable member for Maribyrnong ( Mr Griffiths), asking him for details. He responded in August 1991. speaker: Mr Cadman
theText: I wish to draw the House's attention not so much to the industry problemsMC 1644 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 of animals and their products into Australia. The procedure followed varies in the detail depending on the perceived risks and similarity of the proposal to pre-existing protocols. There are however some basic steps which are common to all major policy decisions such as producing new importation policies. These are characterised by extensive consultation with scientific and industrial bodies eg the state and Northern Territory agriculture departments or equivalent, the Australian Veterinary Association (AVA), the CSIRO and the National Farmers Federation (NFF). Specialist national industry groups such as the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council and the Australian Poultry Industry Association, are also approached when their industry is involved. Overseas experts and organisations are also frequently consulted on specialised topics and the Veterinary Services of the exporting countries provide information on animal health in those countries. The AQIS Bulletin, a monthly publication available through the Australian Government Publishing Service, carries notices of AQIS's reviews and solicits comments. Through this consultative mechanism, AQIS obtains the best scientific information on which to base its decisions. I think that is a good letter, and it outlines, pretty fairly, the way in which Australia should look at these matters. There is another factor that I will raise later. It is the need for Australia to preserve its unique position, in intensely competitive markets, of having disease free, clean food products. That is something that is a priceless comparative advantage to us in any market. It is something that we need to preserve, because too many would want to see us destroy our comparative advantage of clean products and would want to see extra costs loaded onto Australian producers if we should import disease. The former minister's letter, of 21 August 1991, seems a reasonable letter. I decided, at that time, to test the minister's response and take up with the international expert bodies exactly what AQIS had done in order to consult widely. I had already consulted the Australian Veterinary Association, the CSIRO and the NFF. I had spoken to and received documentation from the Australian Pig Industry Council and the Australian Poultry Industry Association. The only group that I was unfamiliar with and did not have information from was the group of overseas experts that AQIS had consulted in giving advice to the government on whether or not Australia should import pig meat. I wrote to the universities and national institutions the names of which the minister supplied as having been consulted. I was somewhat surprised by the responses I received. Let me read some of the names of those authorities which were consulted by AQIS as being world authorities which could provide advice on which a scientific decision as to whether or not Australia should import pig meat could be based. The list reads: Agriculture Canada, Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Australian Veterinary Association, Bureau of Rural Resources, Cambridge University, Chief Quarantine Officers (Animals) in all states and NT, Counsellor (Veterinary Services) Brussels, Iowa State University, Malaysian Veterinary Research Institute, New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Singapore Department of Primary Production, State Veterinary Institute for Virus Research, Denmark, United Kingdom Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, United States Department of Agriculture, University of Melbourne, University of Queensland and Veterinary Counsellor, Washington. I wrote to those groups and I would like now to read some of the responses to the House, because I believe that what we have before us is misleading, if not fraudulent, behaviour on the part of AQIS, in the way in which it spoke to the minister and provided advice to the minister. I will read first of all a letter from the British High Commissioner. It says: Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1645 Dear Mr Cadman, In his letter to you of 2 August the High Commissioner (who is currently travelling with a visiting British Minister) said that we would be asking our Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food if they could provide copies or details of any submissions made by them or by Cambridge University to the inquiry conducted by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) into the import of Canadian pigmeat. The Ministry have now replied saying that they have no trace of any such submissions. I understand that it is quite possible that any contribution which they may have made to the AQIS inquiry would have been provided as answers. to specific questions put to them by AQIS, rather than in the form of a written submission. A very nice informal approach on such a serious issue, I would have thought, and one completely unacceptable in such important decision taking. The letter continues: The officials concerned would not necessarily have known that the questions were being asked in relation to an inquiry into Canadian pigmeat. I am sorry to say, therefore, that on the face of it we are unable to meet your request. But if you are able to provide any more detailed information about the dates on which consultations took place, preferably with the names of officials involved, I should be happy to make further inquiries. I could not do that, but the British High Commission had full details of the statements by the minister and what the minister said. I had a response from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, from the Bureau of Rural Resources, which gave me some breakdown on costs and charges on an economic basis, from the pig meat people of Australia, from the New Zealand government and from the government of the United States. I would have to say that in every instance of my contact with overseas experts, the response was similar to that of the British High Commission. If contact had been made, it was not known by the Australian representatives on their inquiries with universities, or with specialist groups. It is of deep concern to me that, based on what appears to be false and misleading information, we as a nation made a decision based on a very cooperative attitude from the Canadian government, which had a wonderful relationship with the Australian department and the minister and which said, 'There is no risk whatsoever of our pig meat bringing in disease to Australia, and here are the authorities and bodies that we wish to quote.' I would say that is prejudiced advice and, if the Australian government makes decisions in this way, I think that we are in a dangerous situatiori. We have before us the proposition that Australia should import chicken meat from Thailand, Denmark and the United States. I have to use this opportunity t() raise my deep concern that this not become another process of the type that we saw undertaken by the Australian government or its advisers in regard to pig meat. Fortunately, there have not been any grave consequences of the pig meat importation, though there may have been one outbreak of mystery swine disease created by the import of that Canadian pig meat-nobody has been able to say yes or no. Are we going to face the prospect of our poultry industry and then our beef industry and other industries being treated in this same way? The minister's letters are very revealing, because the basis of the decision used by AQIS and the government is not on a norisk policy but on what is an acceptable risk, so there is an endeavour to evaluate the cost of importing an exotic disease and the economic loss against the gain. In the chicken meat industry, the economic gain to consumers is said to be about $3 million a year. The cost to the industry if there were an outbreak of Newcastle disease is estimated, on average, at about $30 million a year. So if we get one outbreak in a lO-year period, any economic advantage is lost immediately.. MC 1646 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 In examining the AQIS position, I turned to AQIS's pamphlet on Newcastle disease, which is the disease most likely to threaten the Australian poultry industry. The pamphlet says: Newcastle disease, the most feared avian disease in the world has penetrated into most countries. Australia so far is free from the pathogenic forms of this disease. When the disease first enters a country it can cause havoc in the bird industry---commercial flocks, fancy birds, pet birds and native wild birds are all susceptible. Thousands of birds may die. Those that appear to recover can pass the disease on to healthy birds and may themselves remain chronically ill for the rest of their lives. There is no known cure for Newcastle Disease. The disease is caused by a virus so drugs do not help. Birds continue dying even if heavily medicated. That is from an AQIS pamphlet on Newcastle disease. I sought some expert information. Dr Balkar Bains-who is one of the most widely respected authorities on poultry disease in the world-states that the possibility of introducing Newcastle disease through imports of cooked meat is real, that the spread of the disease could not be controlled and that it could decimate the native bird population of Australia. He says, 'The evidence is not speculative, it is real.' I know and admire Dr Paul· Gilchrist, as a person who has contributed mightily to the Australian poultry industry and to knowledge on avian diseases, and would be the most widely recognised authority on poultry diseases in New South Wales. He has recently written papers called 'Newcastle disease is a threat to native birds' and 'Further comment-response to the AQIS position'. He says: Researches (1985) reported 100% cent mortality in Eastern Rosellas within six (6) days of artificial exposure to Newcastle Disease.' He also says: Researches (1989) tested 1,235 Australian birds of 130 species for Newcastle Disease virus and antibodies and none gave a positive response. This tends to confirm the lack of exposure of and thus probable susceptibility of our native birds. That is from Dr Paul Gilchrist. If we set the poultry industry to one side and go to the scientific evidence, we can see that AQIS has been derelict in chasing hard scientific evidence. We have two eminent world authorities, both Australians, saying there is a real risk to Australian native bird life here, and we have AQIS continuing to pursue the line with the minister-and with the Australian parliament-that there is an acceptable risk to bringing poultry meat into Australia. I have to raise serious doubts about whether or not we are pursuing a proper course here. I would like to see a full inquiry as to the advice provided by AQIS and the thoroughness of its investigations in all of these matters. I would like to see a detailed analysis of how AQIS arrives at what is an 'acceptable risk', because it seems to me that a 10 to one bet on whether or not there is going to be an outbreak is not an acceptable risk. I would like to see it be more like a 100 to one risk factor if we were even going to contemplate this process. Let me return to what I think is the nub of the whole situation, which is Australia's comparative advantage over the rest of the world. We have, at close quarters, some very active and highly productive countries. We live in a fiercely competitive world, in terms of agricultural products. If we are not going to defend the comparative advantage we have with clean food products, then we ought to pack up the Australian primary industries right now, because it is a philosophy that one cannot apply to one industry and not to another. It is no Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1647 good for the beef growers of Australia to say that we could do without some elements of the poultry industry. The way the argument runs, an acceptable risk is if there is a small economic advantage. I have illustrated the small economic advantage to the consumers of Australia. With $3 million a year spread over hundreds of millions of pieces of poultry consumed by Australians in a year, the advantage for the individual consumer is infinitesimal. If you said to the average Aussie, 'I would like you to pay 25c more a bird to make sure that we do not import disease, and our guarantee is that we are not going to let Newcastle disease into the Australian parrot population,' the kids of Australia would rise up in their schools and say, 'We will pay 25c to make sure that Australia remains disease free.' This is not a protectionist issue. The degree to which this argument on protection has gone on based on animal diseases is stupid, because we are running a risk of denying ourselves the comparative advantage that we have in an intensely competitive world trade in animal and agricultural products. Unless we stay with some semblance of being disease free and can sell without fear or favour around the world Australian products which are known to be disease free, then we will become like the rest of the world and, despite the economies of production, the tyranny of distance will kill our producers. I raise this in what I know is basically a beef debate. But I do so because I am really concerned about the direction I see the protection of Australian animals, flocks and vegetable products going. Our crops are also facing the same sort of threat. I will wait with great interest to hear from the minister the assertions and support that he cannot give in his correspondence, because he does say in the last few lines of his correspondence that there is no guarantee. He says that AQIS cannot give a guarantee that Australian flocks would be free of Newcastle disease. I think this is a terrible decision. (Time expired) industry and I would like to raise the simple question: how are these new proposals being put forward by the government really going to tackle the central problems facing the meat industry today? This is what ought to be concerning all honourable members and it seems to me that it is the one area that the government seems to have skirted around. In fact, one would have to say that we could judge them as being a failure. We do not have to go any further than the Industry Commission report on meat processing released in July last year, which was quite a while ago when you think about it. The government has had all this time to address some of the core problems. Instead of doing that, we are now going off onto another tangent, changing a lot of the structures around the meat industry but, at the same time, avoiding the primary problem. In the overview of the Industry Commission report, which has a very informative way of putting the problems in perspective, it says in part: ... Australia produces livestock at very low cost by international standards. However, efficient processing is necessary if we are to take full advantage of our comparative advantage in livestock production. Although Australian meat is generally price competitive on export markets, this is largely because processors are able to buy livestock at very low prices compared with processors in other countries .. I think that puts it in a very stark perspective. The report goes on to say: This· inquiry has found that,· despite some recent improvements, Australia's meat processing industry operates at significantly higher cost than processing industries of most countries with which it competes.
