speaker: Mr Hawker (Wannon) (11.34 A.m.)
theText: I will address my remarks mainly to the meatMC 1648 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 It has also found that Australian meat exports have been losing market share in almost all our major export markets. I would suggest to all honourable members that there are two very strong messages there. One is the fact that our processing costs are higher than those of our competitors, which is only compensated for by the fact that livestock producers are being paid less. The other more chilling fact is that we are losing market share in almost all our major export markets. I would have thought that the alarm bells would be going off. I find it most disconcerting to listen to some of the government members who seem to be completely avoiding this point and are not able to come to grips with it. . What is even more galling about this is to listen to the comments that the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) made which were reported by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the member for Gwydir( Mr Anderson), in his address. He said that, when asked a question about the problems of the high processing costs, the Prime Minister said, 'Aren't you a mug for highlighting the inefficiency of the Australian beef producer.' The Prime Minister obviously completely misunderstood the industry; he had no idea. I would have thought that that same description could be applied to many of the contributions by government members to this debate. BeforeI leave the Industry Commission report, I want to look very closely at the point that was made in the overview which seems to have escaped government members completely. They come in here like robots and suggest that members of the coalition are just knocking the workers and all they want to do is get lower wages. Talk about ignorant! They obviously have not even read the report. If we look at page 16 of the overview, we will find some comments about the industrial relations problems which really are the core issue in this whole question of trying to get a more efficient meat processing industry. The report says: The industry has been disadvantaged by a poor industrial relations climate and a poor occupational health and safety record. Remember, we are talking about an industry that has had this problem for many years, but, equally, we are talking about a government that has been in power for 12 years and has done, mighty little to address the problem. The report continues: Features of the industry'S award system inhibit innovation and have contributed to industrial Unrest. Seniority systems and daily hire provide insufficient incentives for training and skills development. The complexity of the tally system, and its structure of premium rates of remuneration for extra output, reduces incentives for improving working conditions and productivity. Capacity utilisation of the Australian industry is lower than that of our competitors, resulting in higher fixed costs per unit of output. Further on, it says: The Commission has foundthis is the important pointthat greater flexibility-particularly greater use of enterprise agreements---could bong about significant productivity gains, with benefits. I emphasise this pointfor workers, producers, processors and some consumers. Obviously, the government members were unable to get this far into the report to see that what is being proposed by the Industry Commission-the core issue-is actually going to be for Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1649 the benefit of the workers, not to their disadvantage, as people like the member for Leichhardt ( Mr Dodd) tried to claim when they came in and made their contributions. It seems extraordinary that it has taken report after report to highlight what has been so obvious to so many in the industry who have understood what has been going on for some years. Australia is the net loser because of the government's failure to act. We now have a package of bills which does not address that core issue but does a number of other things such as increase the minister's power over the structures to run the industry. It fails to address some of the major problems with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, as my colleague the member for Mitchell( Mr Cadman) was discussing in his contribution, and it still does not address the primary problem of how we make the meat industry more competitive on an international scale. I guess that, as usual, the government wants to be seen to be doing something, rather than getting in and tackling the central points. If we look at one of the claims in these bills themselves, apart from the fact those opposite do not address some of these core issues, there is a claim that there is no cost in introducing these changes to the AMLC. As I think anyone would know, if significant changes are made to the structures that are operating, it is likely to cause quite a lot of dislocation and there will be some costs, not only directly but indirectly, as people try to adjust to those changes. Clearly, they will have some difficulty in focusing on some of the core issues as they make those adjustments. If we take the question of market information, there is no explanation there as to whether or not the quality or, indeed, the quantity of market information is going to be improved by this change. A second point is about the question of a minister increasing his power in the whole issue. He has now been given two very key powers: he can veto or, indeed, vary the corporate plans of the Meat Industry Council, the Meat· and Livestock Corporation or the Meat Research Corporation. So that is very significant power-a power not only to veto but also to vary. He can have a very big degree of influence and involvement through the guidelines, approvals and appointments of key people on the boards of the various bodies. This is fraught with danger. There is a very real risk that, if a minister wanted to abuse that position, he could do enormous danger to this industry by appointing his cronies or people who are not competent to do the job to the best of their ability. I flag this concern because I think it is something that the government ought to be held accountable for. Clearly, by vesting so much power in a minister, there is a very real risk that the industry could suffer. We only have to look at the last two ministers for primary industry to see some of the shortcomings that I am referring to. When it comes to the meat industry, we have had a choice between two ministers-the current minister who seems to know nothing about the industry, and the previous minister who really did nothing. That is the choice we have had with this current government: the know-nothing or the do-nothing. I now come to my third point, which concerns the whole question of AQIS, the Quarantine and Inspection Service. Again, if we look at the Industry Commission's report, we find that it suggests that AQIS should be split into two. We clearly need more competitiveness in the whole question of meat inspection. I do not think it is good enough to continue to have a complete monopoly, as AQIS currently has. I think it is worth also reminding honourable members that meat inspection is a most expensiveA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 11.44 a.m. to 12.06 p.m. MC 1650 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 Mr HA WKER-As I was saying, one of the areas that does require some attention, as the Industry Commission report has pointed out, is the whole question of inspection services. Meat inspection in Australia costs producers around $90 million a year. That is not an insignificant sum, especially when you look at what some of our competitors pay. For example, in the United States, they pay nothing; meat inspection is provided by the government. One of the other points that is long overdue for recognition is the need to change our inspection system. As I said, this should involve not only splitting AQIS into two, but also looking at a system similar to the HACCP, the hazard analysis critical control point system, on the whole of meat inspection. One of the concerns is that, at the moment, we basically rely on end-point inspection which really only allows a quick glance at the appearance of the meat and clearly could easily overlook some of the possible problems that the whole inspection service is designed to avoid. Today's consumers require more than just a visual inspection. They want the microbiological tests. They want to make sure that the product is clean and that problems that are undetectable to the eye have, in fact, been avoided. Clearly, if we are going to do that, all stages of the processing chain, from the time of transport and from production itself, have to be looked at and what we might call a quality assurance system has to be instituted. This would not only guarantee a safer product but would also, I think, guarantee a better product. That is the whole point of this HACCP system because it eliminates this fisk. Therefore I think it is time that we started to look at this, instead of the government continuing with the existing system which clearly has some shortcomings. This would dovetail very nicely into some of the work that the Cattle Council has been doing in developing its quality assurance program. The fourth point, and probably the most significant one, is the whole question of industrial relations. As has been shown in the Industry Commission report-and was, in fact, shown in the Booz Allen and Hamilton report a couple of years ago-we do have a major problem in the cost of processing in Australia. That is why we are in the alarming position where not only are Australian processing costs much higher and Australian producers are receiving less than their counterparts in other countries but, at the same time, we are losing market share in many of our export markets. Part of the industrial relations problem that has been highlighted also adds to the fact that our processing costs are, in many cases, double that of the New Zealanders and more than twice what it costs to process in the United States. We can look at other parts of the chain, for example, the whole waterfront system. We have seen $430 million spent there, half of it provided by taxpayers, yet if we look at the latest Contship assessment, the performance of Australian ports is slipping back down the list. So all that money has been spent only to see that our performance is deteriorating when it is compared with that of other ports around the world. I have highlighted the industrial relations problem as it affects the meat industry in the processing area. I have mentioned the problems in the waterfront. We could also look at some of the inefficiencies in transport. But I come back to the point I made that was highlighted in the Industry Commission report: it is not a question, as some of the honourable members opposite have tried to portray it, of trying to force workers into poorer conditions or lower wages. It is quite the opposite. It is by increasing the productivity and by getting greater efficiency that, in fact, everyone can benefit. It is a tragedy for this industry and the country that Australian meat processors and producers have to pay a very high price for a system which all commentators in this country have Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1651 recognised is inefficient. Only the Labor Party seems unable to realise that we are putting a major impediment in the way of improving our export performance in this industry and, indeed, in just about every other industry. Producers are the ones who are suffering. It has been estimated that the average cattle producer in Australia is getting from $50 to $100 per head less than they would be getting if Australia had a world competitive system for processing and transporting products. This was illustrated very clearly by a recent example when Queensland, ostensibly because of the drought problem, found itself in a position where it had to import beef from United States and New Zealand. After paying all the costs of shipping that meat to Australia-and cattle producers in the United States are paid far more than the Australian producers-the beef could still be landed in Queensland at a competitive price compared with the Australian product. More clearly than anything else, that illustrates what a dreadful problem we have and, as I see it, the legislation does virtually nothing to address it. It is a forerunner to some of the other problems that the industry is going to face if we do not get efficiency into the whole process. Already it is clear that parts of South America are going to be able to send their meat into the United States and we will find that that will be very competitive. I would like to point out one issue which I think the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) has made a lot of noise about, that is, the importance of getting women involved in some of these associated boards. Everyone would agree with the thrust of that, but, when he talks about having quotas, it raises some concerns. Looking at government appointments to date, it is very hard to find people other than men. The most recent appointment, which only reinforces this point, has been to the position of chairman of the Meat and Livestock Corporation. It was none other than the former minister for primary industry, Mr Kerin. The government representative on the Meat Industry Council is a man, the government representative on the ILC is a man, and the Meat Research Council is headed up by a man. Most of these people are very competent, but I do not think the government's record is followed up by its rhetoric. In conclusion, I would like to raise these concerns again because one of our major primary industries is being sorely hampered by the fact that the government has failed to address the key issue of getting efficiency into the whole process. The Industry Commission· report highlighted the core problem of getting efficiency into processing and boils the problem down to the government being rusted onto an archaic industrial relations system while the rest of the world looks on in utter amazement. Clearly, the government has failed miserably to serve the best interests of our industry and to serve the best interests of Australia in addressing this problem. A division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 12.15 p.m. to 12.37 p.m. beef industry in Australia. These are landmark pieces of legislation, very important, and I want . to reiterate a few points that have been made by the opposition during this debate. The first point is that it needs to be highlighted that it has taken the government 14 months to respond to this Industry Commission report. This is not just a one-off situation as far as government responding to IC reports is concerned. The taxpayers of Australia put an enormous amount of resource into getting these professionally done and objective reports of industry analysis.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Vaile (Lyne) (12.37 P.m.)
theText: This package of bills will have a profound effect on theMC 1652 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday,S June 1995 At the moment we are also waiting on a report that is with a government minister and has been for 12 months-that is, the IC report on the petroleum industry in Australia. There has still been no response from the government in that regard, yet that also has an effect on this industry. It has taken 14 months for the governm-nt to respond to this Industry Commission report. I suppose that, if we look at some of the comments and recommendations that have been made in the IC report, we can understand why it has taken the government so long to respond to the report. The beef industry is one of Australia's most vitally important rural industries. We are very much world competitive, for reasons differing from those that the government recognises. Previous opposition speakers have passed criticism of the fact that this bill is being debated in the national parliament of Australia when the minister is overseas. We are not criticising the fact that the minister is overseas; we recognise that he has got to do that to do his job adequately in representing the rural industries of Australia. But it is probably an indication of where in the scale of the importance of things the government places the beef industry, when the government is prepared to run this legislation through in the second chamber when the minister is overseas. That needs to be put on the record. I know that there has been a fair amount of criticism levelled at the shadow minister for primary industry for making the same comments, but it is certainly worth putting it on the record that I think the government should have placed a little bit more importance on this package of legislation, which is very important to the prosperity of the beef industry. This package of legislation is complex. I was involved in the livestock selling business and auctioneering business in a former life, and so I can understand the frustration which many of my constituents have expressed to me with regard to recent levy charges and levy changes. It can be seen that the main bill is giving effect to the Meat Industry Council, and I understand that a great many of the other bills have the effect of transferring to the Meat Industry Council the ability to charge the levies which are already being paid. It is interesting to see which organisations are to be on the Meat Industry Council, and, indeed, the details of the composition of the council jumped off the page at me when I first read it. There are to be 18 members and the council will include a chairperson and a government member, both of whom will be appointed by the minister. The minister will also appoint other members on the recommendation of the Cattle Council of Australia, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia, the Australian Meat Council, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Livestock Exporters Association, the Australian Lot Feeders Association, the Australian Supermarket Institute Limited and other members prescribed by regulation. Although it is not enunciated in any of the documentation that I have read in the course of my research, I would hope that, under that last criterion of 'other members prescribed by regulation', there is a representative from the Livestock Agents Association. Livestock agents are the people who, on behalf of the AMLC, and, in the future; the Meat Industry Council, collect levies. They are the people who have got to deal with the producers and explain to them what it is all about when the levy goes up. Livestock agents also have to explain how the money is being spent. Although as the collectors for the Commonwealth the livestock agents cop the blame, I do not see them listed as members of that body. I have not researched the situation any further, and they may be involved as other members prescribed by regulation. I certainly hope so. Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1653 I reiterate the absolute importance of having someone on the council who represents livestock selling agents from across Australia. There are a number of peak bodies in the states from which it would be possible to draw some very experienced people. I do not disagree with the selection of the other representatives on the council; their selection is obviously justifiable. However, although there are producers, processors, retailers and wholesalers represented on the council, the key conduit person from the middle of the process is not represented. It does not matter whether the product is consumed domestically or whether it is exported; the fact is that a large percentage of the beef cattle in Australia which are processed through saleyards are processed through livestock selling agents. It is very important that that fact is recognised, and I hope that the government takes what I have said on board. The government has obviously left a little flexibility at the margin so that someone else in that area can be included. The Australian Council of Trade Unions is included, and that is fine because many of the members of the union are involved in the beef industry in areas such as production and processing, transport, retailing and overseas shipment. However, do not forget a very important element: the livestock agents are the people who collect the levies for the Commonwealth in those circumstances. It is very important that livestock agents be included on the Meat Industry Council. The government asked the Industry Commission to undertake a study into the meat industry, and the commission reported to the government in July 1994. I have already made the point that the report had·been with the government for 14 months before a response and this draft legislation was received. In its report, the Industry Commission pointed out that Australia produces livestock at avery low cost by international standards. However, efficient processing is necessary if Australia is to take full advantage of our comparative advantage in livestock production. The comparative advantage in livestock production in this country comes from the producers. It does not come from anywhere else along the chain; it comes from the producers. We have the most efficient producers of beef in the world and this is because the prices that our producers receive for their product are very low by world standards. The Industry Commission report said that the reason Australia remains world competitive in this area is that processors are able to buy livestock at very low prices compared with the prices paid by processors in other countries. I can confidently state that this is a fact. There are a lot of members on both sides of this chamber who have direct links to the beef industry in the production, wholesale .or processing areas. The members concerned know that returns to beef producers have not progressed in real terms with the rest of the economy, and the members concerned all know that, in a lot of cases, returns have gone backwards. Returns are subject to the whims of the market. This was recently borne out when US beef landed in Australia at competitive prices after cattle producers in the United States were paid 60 per cent more for their livestock than Australian farmers. There is not much room for any improvement as far as our primary producers are concerned. They are becoming world competitive. This government has signed the GATT agreement and the World Trade Organisation comes into effect from 1 July 1995. In those agreements, as far as the reduction of tariff and subsidy is concerned, particularly in regard to primary products, it is on a percentage basis across-the board off different bases. The Australian Commonwealth and its producers were already receiving low subsidy and low tariff protection. Off that base, in the first year we are reducing MC 1654 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 our tariffs by 20 per cent, whereas Great Britain and countries in the European Union are reducing from enormously high levels of tariff protection in excess of 100 per cent. I just do not see how we are ever going to be really competitive in that area. The European Union and the United States of America still do not seem to be committed to the moral ethic of the Uruguay Round. Recently, the US introduced extra SUbsidies on dairy products into South-East Asia. It is going to be interesting to see, when the time comes, what we will do and what the World Trade Organisation will do when the US does not comply. It is doubly difficult for our primary producers. They are not supported in a genuine way by the rest of the industry as far as reform is concerned. Reform is not happening in a number of areas. In the processing sector, it is not happening adequately or quickly, noris it happening in the government sector-for instance, AQIS and its services. All Australian processors have committed themselves to quality assurance programs. In my electorate, a couple of processing plants, have gone the whole hog and spent an enormous amount of money on quality assurance. They have their own quality assurance people in place but the number of AQIS people has not been reduced. That is a burden in itself. It adds to the high cost of the end product that is not relevant to what the producer has to put up with. The government has not responded to a number of issues from the IC report. One of the documents I was researching was interesting. It says: While there has been an extensive consultation process leading to the introduction of this package of Bills, a major reservation can be identified. This is that the process was conducted against the background of issues raised in the Industry Commission report and the Discussion Paper and these, almost exclusively, focussed on perceived deficiencies in current arrangements, and concerns over the effectiveness of AMLC programs. Consequently, relatively scant attention appears to have been paid to those aspects of the present meat marketing system which are operating satisfactorily. Nor has there been any indication of the tangible benefits that presumably would flow from the package or of what, if any, the costs might be. The assertion that the proposed arrangements will provide a less regulatory operating environment for the industry is not yet supported by any evidence. While there has been a rearrangement of the roles and powers of various statutory bodies, in total the same array of objectives, functions and powers will largely endure. Furthermore, the proposed arrangements do not give industry a full self-determination role in policy and industry development because of two key powers vested in the Minister. These are the power to veto/vary MIC, AMLC and MRC ... directives with respect to performance of MIC, AMLC and MRC functions and powers. The Minister will also have;: a degree of influence and involvement through the likes of guidelines and approvals (such as appointments and export licences). It remains to be seen whether or not those who want the role of the AMLC phased down or out ... or those who wish to see statutory marketing and information continue ... can be reconciled, particularly given the MIC's levy setting responsibility. Given that there has to date been no commercial evaluation, or rigorous analysis of the worth of the AMLC and MRC to the meat and live-stock industry, it is possible that a minimally staffed MIC will not be able to mount well thought through proposals without the information base of the AMLC and MRC. The Australian meat and live-stock industries have not reconciled the age-old conflict between producers and processors to the extent that has occurred in the dairy industry. That is an absolute matter of fact. They have not been reconciled. There is not a whole of industry commitment to the outcomes that we want to see achieved in the beef industry, and that is so very true. Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1655 We wholeheartedly support the arrangements that have been in place under the Kerin plan and then the Crean plan. The opposition supported the arrangements that we have moved the dairy industry into, so that it can take on the agreements that we have signed concerning the World Trade Organisation, which comes into place on 1 July this year. But we have not got that whole of industry commitment by the beef industry. There are too many tensions, there is not the commitment to the outcome and there is not the fairness of the down-flow of benefit to the people that deserve it. We see the producers in times of drought receiving lower and lower margins. We see producers in good times, in flush times, being penalised because of corrupt overseas markets. When the market is bad, the people that bear the brunt of it are not the processing plants or the people that work in the processing plants, they are not the transport operators or the shipping people that take the containers over the wharves. Who are they? It is the producers that bear the brunt of it. Instead of getting $400 for a beast, they get $200 for a beast and have got to shut up and take it. They have absolutely no redress at all because those producers might have one sale a year. They might breed weaners for sale into a fattening market, and they have one sale a year. If that sale happens to fall in a time of low prices, they have no choice but to take what they are offered. That illustrates that there is no commitment right across the industry to see fair and equitable distribution of the profits of the industry back to the people who produce the goods and the other people involved in the industry who have got major investment. Without the producers, without the processors, the employees along the way would not have the jobs that they have got. It is very important that in the industry, and at this level of setting industry policy, these facts are recognised. To date I do not believe they are. It is interesting to note the amendment that has been moved by the shadow minister. I will put it on the record again: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Main Committee deplores the fact that the Government has implemented only one of the Industry Commission's recommendations for the industry and has ignored the others, including important recommendations relating to industrial relations reform and the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service". I have covered both those points in my address this afternoon and I go back to the other main points that I started with as far as this vitally important industry is concerned. It has taken all that time for the government to respond, in drafting this legislation, to that IC report; the government has addressed only a couple of the recommendations in that IC report; and it is running this legislation through the national parliament of Australia with the minister overseas. I am not decrying the fact that he is actually overseas working on behalf of the producers of Australia. I am just pointing out that the scheduling of this legislation when he is not here is an indication to us on this side of the House of the level of importance that the government places on this industry, which is absolutely vital. We are not seeing a genuine attitude towards all the government members' constituents that work in this industry, to try to see the ongoing viability of the industry and to see a fair and equitable distribution of the profits that flow from this industry in Australia. Most important is the fact that, in all the documentation that I have read, there does not seem to be any reference to the possibility of having a representative of any of the livestock agents associations around Australian represented on the Meat Industry Council. They are an MC 1656 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 absolutely vital link in the chain in this industry in Australia. They are the people who actually collect all the levies that this legislation is putting into place, for the Meat Industry Council to collect. They are the people with whom the bureaucrats in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy should be liaising. They should be told, 'This is how you explain it to the producers. This is what we were are doing with the money. It is all about making sure that our product maintains a very high reputation overseas.' We all agree with that sentiment. We agree with what has been done. The producers do not know that; that message is not getting across. The message is not getting down to those livestock agents. I implore the government to have a look at that particular area under the category 'other members prescribed by regulation' so that there is some representative of the livestock agents to give them input into what is going to be a very important body in the future. read a second time. To this the Deputy Leader of the National Party has moved as an amendment that all words after 'that' be admitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question. All those of that opinion say aye; to the contrary no. I think the noes have it. The question now is that this bill be now read a second time. All those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I think the ayes have it. Mrs SullivanMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order, I think I should just point out that when you put the question that the motion is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question you ruled for the noes. immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question. All those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I think the ayes have it. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole. Mr O'KEEFE (Burke-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport) (12.59 p.m.)-by Ieave-I move: (1) Clause 142, page 60, line 12, omit "inspector", substitute "officer". (2) Clause 145, page 62, line 12, omit "inspector", substitute "authorised officer". I table the corrigendum to the explanatory memorandum. Amendments agreed to. Bill, as amended, agreed to. amendments.

theText: The question is that the bill be reporteto theMC 1660 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 Cognate bill: Consideration resumed from 11 May. Second Reading Mr O'KEEFE (Burke-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport) (1.15 p.m.)I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on jet aircraft landings at airports where noise amelioration programs are being funded by the federal government. Honourable members will be aware that construction of a new parallel runway at Sydney airport was completed during 1994, and the runway came into operation in November 1994. When the recently installed air traffic control system is operating at full capacity, the traffic handling capacity of the new runway configuration will be about 80 aircraft movements per hour, compared with 55 movements per hour prior to the commissioning of the new runway. While the operation of the new parallel runway configuration significantly reduces the overall number of people seriously affected by aircraft noise, particularly among those to the east and west of the airport, it significantly increases the level of noise exposure for residents of some other areas, mainly to the north of the airport. Recognising that this would be the case, the government, in 1991, commissioned a steering committee, convened by the Federal Airports Corporation, to prepare a noise management plan for Sydney airport, identifying possible measures to mitigate the noise impact of the new runway operation. A draft noise management plan was subsequently developed, with extensive involvement by the three levels of government, the community and the airline industry. The draft plan was released for public comment in June 1994. After considering measures proposed in the draft noise management plan, the government announced late last year that it would undertake a major program of acquisition and acoustic insulation of certain buildings in the areas worse affected by noise from the operation of the airport. In addition, the government has initiated a range of other measures, including mandatory flight paths, take-off procedures for jet aircraft and tighter curfew arrangements, to minimise the number of people affected by aircraft noise. The acquisition and insulation program encompasses the voluntary acquisition of up to 113 residential properties within the 40 ANEF zone; sound insulation of some 4,200 residential properties within the 30 ANEF zone; and sound insulation of schools and colleges, child-care facilities, hospitals and health care facilities and churches within the 25 ANEF zone. The scope of eligibility for this program is at least equal to that at any major overseas airport where a noise amelioration program is in place. It is the government's intention that the announced program be completed within a three-year period. This, again, compares favourably with the rate of implementation of overseas programs. Based on indicative cost data developed in conjunction with the draft noise management plan, the cost of the program was originally estimated at some $183 million. Following a reassessment of eligible buildings and the scope and cost of required works, the estimated overall cost of the program is now $260 million, in 1995-96 prices. Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1661 The airlines and their passengers will be the beneficiaries of the increased runway capacity created at Sydney airport. It follows that they should be required to meet the cost of reducing the noise impacts on the affected communities in the vicinity of the airport. The levy which this bill seeks to impose will provide the mea-s for giving effect to this principle. The bill provides that the levy will apply only at declared airports, which are those where the following conditions apply: · there are residences or public buildings in noise affected areas (as defined by ANEF contours) around the airport, · there is or has been a federal government funded airport noise amelioration program in place, and · the amount of levy collected at a given time is not in excess of the costs to the federal government of the noise amelioration program. The levy will apply, in the first instance, to Sydney airport only. This recognises the very significant change in noise patterns around the airport which results from the opening of the new runway. The government similarly expects that, where new runway developments or extensions enabling a significant change in either the number or type of jet aircraft usages occur at other major airports, the need for noise amelioration programs will also arise. Honourable members will be aware that the government has embarked on a program of leasing federal airports. As part of the next stage of the disposal process, the government will examine how best to ensure responsible environmental behaviour by users and operators of leased airports. Prospective airport operators will clearly have an interest in the development of environmental management measures, including noise amelioration, which may be warranted by significant runway works and changes in operations at the airports which they will be leasing. These leases will, therefore, be addressed in the context of the airport leasing program which will see the first of our major federal airports leased in 1996. Turning to the levy itself, the amount of levy payable per jet aircraft landing will be determined according to a formula developed as part of the Sydney airport draft noise management plan. The formula provides that the noisier an aircraft the higher will be the rate of levy payable per landing. For example, the amount of levy payable for a landing by a Boeing 747 will be some three to four times higher than for a Boeing 737, depending on the specific noise characteristics of the particular aircraft. The bill provides for the levy to apply to landings by jet aircraft only. This retlects the fact that generally jet aircraft create greater noise disturbance than propeller driven aircraft. There will be some quiet small jet aircraft which are not liable for the levy. It is a requirement of the bill that revenue from the levy at a particular declared airport not exceed the cost of the noise amelioration program at that airport. To spread the cost impact on airlines, it is not envisaged that the levy will necessarily be raised at a rate which keeps pace with spending on the noise amelioration program. The levy rate will be prescribed by regulations subject to the limitations established in the bill. It is proposed that there will be automatic annual adjustments of the levy rates in line with consumer price index movements. The rate will also be periodically reviewed in the light of other parameters, such as growth rates in jet aircraft landings and the cost of noise. amelioration programs that might be established at any other airports. MC 1662 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 It is the government's intention that the rate of levy be initially set at an amount of $155 per noise unit. This rate will be adjusted as necessary so as to enable the cost of the Sydney airport noise amelioration program to be recovered over a period of up to 10 years.· In 1995-96 it is expected that the levy will raise some $32.2 million. This translates to an average cost per jet aircraft passenger landing at Sydney airport of around $3.40. This is a landmark bill. It establishes a regime for recovering from aviation operators the costs of redressing the adverse impact of aircraft noise imposed on communities in the vicinity of airports, immediately in the case of Sydney airport and at other Australian airports in future years. In respect of the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill, the purpose of this bill is to establish a collection regime for the levy imposed by the complementary Aircraft Noise Levy Bill. The levy collection bill specifies in detail by whom, in what circumstances, and when and how the levy is payable. It also covers penalty and enforceinent arrangements and provides the necessary powers to allow the levy to be collected by a Commonwealth authority. It is proposed that the Civil Aviation Authority, or Airservices Australia when it is established, will perform this role. Since the processes for collection of the noise levy readily dovetail with the authority'S own revenue collection activities based on aircraft landings, it is expected that this arrangement will minimise administrative costs associated with the collection of the levy. I commend both bills to the House. That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, this House condemns the Government for its callous and incompetent policy on Sydney Airport, and condemns it in particular: (a) for its decision effectively to close the east west runway; (b) for misleading the people of Sydney about the noise that would be associated with the opening of the parallel runway; and (c) for its failure to develop adequate noise management measures prior to the opening of the parallel runway, rather than after it opened in a belated response to community pressure". I rise on behalf of Senator Parer-who is our shadow minister for aviation and who has responsibility for carriage of this bill through the Senate-and, indeed, on behalf of the opposition generally. I take this opportunity to move my first amendment; I will be moving a second amendment relating to the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill at a later time, when we deal with the bill in detail. This amendment probably bests expresses the views held by many people in Sydney today about the disaster that has been over their heads every day of the year since the opening of the third runway-or the second parallel runway-at Sydney's Mascot airport. I do not think there is a soul living in Sydney-nor, indeed, in New South Wales-who would not be affected by the concerns which these people in Sydney have been drawing to our attention as a consequence of the dramatic increase in noise over the heads of many thousands of people in Sydney since the second parallel runway was opened in the latter months of last year. theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, it was a deal, and it was struck for political purposesMC 1666 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 airport is the talk. We are getting a lot of fast talking from the Minister for Transport ( Mr Brereton) and a lot of slow tracking on Badgerys Creek. Years after this government promised that Badgerys Creek airport would be opened, we still have not seen anything happen out at Badgerys Creek. There has been a steady march of transport ministers since this government came into office in 1983. Over that time, various transport ministers or ministers for aviation have made specific predictions about the completion of Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek. The last minister before the current minister, Senator Bob Collins, made a specific commitment as to the completion date of Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek. That date passed by long ago. Yet this government, the present minister and the Prime Minister are asking the people of Sydney to believe their current speculations about the opening of Sydney West airport within the next few years. On the basis of its track record on Badgerys Creek airport, the government cannot be believed. I believe the only thing that is happening at Sydney West airport is some fast talking and not much action. We are going to find that the people of Sydney will be bothered by these noise problems for a lot longer than the government is prepared to admit. My colleague Senator Parer provided me with some information that was revealed by the New South Wales Environment Protection Authority in its report on aircraft noise. The Environment Protection Authority concluded that many suburbs, including Kurnell, Bundeena and Rozelle, were experiencing annoyingly high levels of aircraft noise, despite the claim in the noise management plan that they would not be affected. In one street the noise level exceeded 80 decibels 26 times an hour and the residents living in that street do not qualify for the insulation program, despite the Australian standard that noise levels in homes should not exceed 60 decibels. That points to the fact that the bill does not deal adequately with the problems of noise for many thousands of Sydneysiders. Even for those Sydneysiders who do qualify for soundproofing of their buildings, schools and homes, this will not resolve all the problems. There have been some 3,000 submissions to the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney. Many of the submissions, which were made by 3,000 residents, are very sceptical about the soundproofing program. For example, one of them said that the recommendation to soundproof buildings and schools is only a partial solution, and that Sydney's mild climate lends itself to outdoor living. What happens when people or children move outside? Do they have insulated space helmets? This is not going to completely solve the problem of aircraft noise for Sydneysiders. At best, it will only partially solve the problem for some of the people who are affected by noise levels from Sydney airport and as a consequence of the second parallel runway being open. I thank my colleague the honourable member for Fadden( Mr Jull) for pointing out to me the other day that there are some rather unusual discrepancies in the way in which the levy for particular aircraft is going to work. He makes the point that the levy actually penalises the quietest jets at the expense of not penalising the noisiest jets as much. For example, a BAe146 will have a levy that is the equivalent of $5.17 per passenger, whereas a 747-400 will have a levy of $3.67 per passenger. Anybody who knows anything about aircraft will tell people that a BAe146 is probably the quietest commercial jet aircraft operating in and out of Sydney at the present time. IfI were a resident of Sydney concerned about noise levels, I would want to ensure that the government was doing its utmost to encourage the use of the quietest possible aircraft, given that Sydney Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1667 airport is going to be a reality for many years. Indeed, the levy on the quietest jet aircraft, that is, the BAe146, is the highest of all the jet passenger aircraft that operate into Sydney's airport. The honourable member for Fadden will go on and explain that in far greater detail in his speech later today, but it is rather inconsistent to be doing it in this fashion. As I say; if! were a resident of Sydney with aircraft roaring over my head, I would want to be encouraging the use of the BAe146 by having either no levy imposed or at least the lightest levy per passenger imposed on that type of aircraft rather than the opposite, which is the way the government has done it. The bill reflects the failure of the government to adequately manage the air traffic noise over Sydney airport. There has been very poor planning in the way in which the government has been developing its air traffic noise management proposals. For example, the original plan was to take 10 years to provide insulation for homes in Sydney that are severely affected by aircraft noise as a result of the second parallel runway. WhilstI am talking about insulation, I will make a little plug for my constituents, who are wool producers. Wool is one of the best forms of sound insulation available today. There is a gentleman in Goulburn who is going to insulate, free of charge, a number of houses-I think one of them is in Rozelle. Some of them might be in the electorate of the honourable member for WatsonMr Leo McLeay-It is nowhere near us. M.r SHARP-I know Rozelle is nowhere near you, but that gentleman will be working in a number of suburbs around Sydney-one of which I hope will be in the honourable member for Watson's electorate-because he is convinced, as are many people, that wool is one of the. most effective sound insulation materials available. I would urge the FAC, and anyone responsible for these insulation programs, to take into account the value of wool. It is extremely valuable in controlling and minimising the effects of noise. There are many concerns raised by Sydneysiders, which are not adequately dealt with in this legislation. The government's propaganda about fast-tracking Badgerys Creek does not fool too many people. Its propaganda about narrowing the flight paths and introducing heavy penalties for those people who breach those flight paths is not going to solve the problem. People know that pilots go where they are told to go. Air traffic control tells the pilots to take a particular heading and to follow a particular track. The trumpeting by the minister, late last year and early this year, of his method of solving the aircraft noise problems over Sydney by having heavy fines for pilots who do not adhere to those flight paths, is going to do very little indeed to solve the problems of aircraft noise resulting from the expansion of Sydney's Mascot airport. It is an issue of considerable concern. My colleague in the Senate Senator Parer, our shadow minister for aviation, will be making very strong representations in the Senate on this issue. I know other members in this House will also be making representations to try to do their best to bring some honesty and openness into the way in which this government deals with the people of Sydney over the aircraft noise problem. I can tell the House-as would the honourable member for Watson, who represents many people in Sydney-that this problem is destroying the lives of people in Sydney. The noise is incredible. I have actually been to some of these places, where the aircraft noise rattles the houses. My mother-in-law lives out in Castle Hill. That might seem a long way from Sydney's airport. Yet, for the first time ever, aircraft are flying over her house and destroying the lifestyle of the people living out there. MC 1668 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 This problem is affecting a very wide area of Sydney, previously never affected by aircraft noise. The people in those areas have a just argument; they bought or built their houses on the basis that they were not under a flight path. They paid prices for their houses that reflected the fact that those parts of Sydney were supposed to be quiet areas. Consequently, the value of their homes has been reduced. All Sydney's federal parliamentary representatives have to be very pro-active on this issue. I hope that they will be. They certainly should be, if they are to represent the interests of their constituents to the best of their abilities . The opposition calls on the government to be open and honest about what is going to happen at Sydney airport; to provide the public with the full details of this latest expansion proposal as revealed in the Sydney Morning Herald today; to provide the public with the truth about what is happening at Badgerys Creek airport because we are not getting the truth on that; to provide the public with the truth about the noise contours over Sydney; to provide the public with the truth as to the actual numbers of people who are affected by this; to do everything within its power to encourage the use of the quietest possible aircraft; and to ensure that the Civil Aviation Authority-or the new Airservices Australia as it will be known after 1 July-is effective in administering the air laws in a way that minimises the impact of noise over the heads of Sydney people. I can tell members now that a lot of people are very sceptical about the way in which this government has been approaching the whole issue of airports in Sydney and at Badgerys Creek and the whole issue of noise pollution over the heads of hundreds of thousands of Sydney siders. We will not, of course, be opposing this bill. The opposition is keen to do whatever is possible to assist in minimising the impact of noise over the heads of Sydney people as a consequence of this government's actions, so we will not be opposing it. I moved our amendment earlier in my presentation this afternoon. When we deal with the bill in detail, I will be moving an additional amendment that I have yet to refer to that deals with the incremental increase in the levy. necessary because the third runway at Sydney airport, the parallel runway, should never have been built. What is even less necessary than this legislation is the second reading amendment moved by the opposition. While listening to the member for Hume( Mr Sharp), I was starting to think that I must have been living on a different planet for the last 25 years. To hear the opposition, the New South Wales National Party and Liberal Party, suggesting that, somehow or other, they had a concern for the noise that was going to be created for Sydneysiders by Sydney airport is hypocrisy on a mind-bending scale. For nearly 30 years, the New South Wales Liberal Party and the federal opposition have had a policy of a parallel runway at Sydney airport. The study that was done in the 1960s concerned a parallel runway at Sydney airport. For the last 15 years, the member for Barton( Mr Punch) and I have been making speeches wherever we could and whenever we could about the problem that was going to be caused by that parallel runway. I first got elected to public life in 1971 on the local council and my program was one of opposition to the expansion of Sydney airport as proposed by Malcolm Fraser, the former Liberal Party Prime Minister. The hypocrisy of these people is absolutely breathtaking.
