It is shown again today in the Sydney Morning Herald that the FAC is not telling people what its plans are. There has been more duplicity and dishonesty by officials in .relation to Sydney airport than in any other exercise in government in the 16 years I have been in this House. It is an ongoing saga of lies and deceit from this GBE. The FAC had the hide to say at one stage that the Minister for Transport ( Mr Brereton) ought to let the FAC bid to buy Sydney airport when the airport is privatised. That is like letting the crooks take over the treasury. The FAC set this thing up, and now it wants. the management to buyout the buyer. Fortunately, the minister decided that he is not going to let that scam occur. The opposition now say, 'It's terrible. It's shocking.' The opposition say that, even though the opposition is part of the problem but not part of the solution. It is a sick joke. After all, it is people like the member for Bennelong ( Mr Howard), who, all of a sudden, has discovered aircraft noise. He says, 'Isn't it terrible? Share the pain. Open the east-west runway.' Of course, when we talked about this earlier-when the proposal was that the government should build the parallel runway and when the government put forward the idea that Badgerys Creek ought to be developed quickly as an· alternate airport to Sydney airport-the member .for Bennelong and his constituents did not like it. This is because, when we look at the studies of where air travellers come from in Sydney, we find a great little concentration of air travellers in the electorate of Bennelong. Travellers from this area do not want to spend a bit of time travelling out to the western suburbs of Sydney to catch their aeroplanes, and they say, 'Oh, it's inconvenient to have to do that.' I say to them that there is no point in their saying that it is inconvenient to travel that far, just asthere is no point in their saying now how inconvenient it is that the poor old real estate prices have fallen and that it is inconvenient to have the planes flying over their heads. As I said earlier, these people are part of the problem, never part of the solution. What we are hearing now is something which is an unfortunate latter-day conversion on the road to Sydney or Badgerys Creek, depending upon how people want to -look at it. If only the opposition-and, indeed, the government-had been able to look at this a bit more carefully. If only members of parliament from all parties had not just been belly-aching and whingeing about how terrible it was that they had to spend 10 minutes circling Sydney airport on Friday afternoon on the way home from parliament, and how awful it was and how we had to get this parallel runway up. They were conned by the FAC that that was going to solve their problem, and they were conned by the airlines. One of the great little hypocritical stories in this is that now we hear the bleatings from Qantas, our so-called wonderful national carrier. These are the people who never did any planning for what they did at Sydney airport, and all they want to do now is Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1671 belly-ache about how terrible it is that the previous Liberal government gave Ansett all the land leases and that they do not have anything there. Yet they have the hide to say that if the government had done some earlier planning about Badgerys Creek then we would not have the problem at Sydney airport. Qantas did not do all that much planning, either. Qantas has not got any land, and its management is in the paper today saying they might have a plan to move their maintenance facility to Brisbane or to Melbourne because the government did not do something. It is the stupidity of the Qantas management in getting into bed with the Federal Airports Corporation and with Ansett in saying the solution to Sydney's airport needs was at Sydney airport with the parallel runway, rather than looking at what happened everywhere else in the world. Everywhere else, there are big airports out on the city rim and smaller airports close to the city, like Kingsford Smith is in Sydney. The reality of this is that the lives of tens of thousands of people in Sydney have been destroyed, and they have been destroyed by politicians on both sides of this House who were short-sighted. They have been destroyed, in particular, by the duplicity and the lying and the dishonesty of the Federal Airports Corporation, the government's own GBE, which allowed these things to happen and did not inform ministers or the public of what it was up to. Its program was always to build everything it possibly could at Sydney airport; and it was aided and abetted by the airlines, which said that the last thing they wanted to do was to move out to Badgerys Creek. James Strong, who allegedly works for the government as the head of a government GBE, says that Qantas's solution to Sydney airport is that everyone else ought to move out. We should get the commuters out of there, and get the charter operators out of there. Essentially, Sydney airport-Kingsford Smith airport-should become Kingsford Smith (Qantas) airport, and everyone else should go out to Badgerys Creek. The reality is that this legislation will provide some funds so that the problem can be ameliorated. The people who are using the aircraft will pay some money towards trying to ameliorate some of the noise pollution that is hitting the tens of thousands of people who live around Sydney airport-many of whom I represent now, and a great deal more of whom I represented when I was the member for Grayndler. There are very few people in this House who have clean hands on this issue. The member for Barton, the member for Grayndler (Ms McHugh), the member for Sydney( Mr Baldwin), the minister and I are a few of the ones who have, because we stood up and said how crook this thing was. At least the people who are going to cause the noise are going to have to pay for some of it now, and I think that is a fair thing. To my mind, one of the few ministers in this country who have actually had some thought about the people who lived around the airport has been the federal transport minister. One of the others was the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). They at least had a concern for the effect that this monstrosity was going to have on the people who lived around the airport. All the other beIly-aching MPs from both sides would come back here on Tuesday mornings and tell me, 'We had to queue up at Sydney airport again on Friday night. Isn't it terrible?' Bad luck. Isn't it terrible that we have inconvenienced some of them? They aU lobbied and went mad down here. The people who live in Marrickville, where I grew up, are actually going mad-literaIly going mad over this. They have these planes day and night. There are some people in the MC 1672 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 opposition who say that is not enough, we have to open it up for 24-hour operations. The government is not going to do that. The EIS was predicated on not reopening the east-west runway for continual traffic, and at least what this levy will do is ensure that part of the problem funds part of the solution. I might sound a little passionate about this, but I do believe that there has been a terrible injustice perpetrated in Sydney. A vast part of the greatest city in this country-indeed, one of the great cities in the world-has been destroyed by this parallel runway set-up at Sydney airport. I am truly of the belief that, if the Federal Airports Corporation had been open and had not concealed the truth about the effect this would have on the people of Sydney, no government would ever have built this monstrosity. But the truth did not come out until after it was done, and no-one is going to say to a government, 'You spent some billions of dollars on this proposal and you have to pull it up.' Where is the FAC now? It is where its plan always was: increase the capital structure and no-one will be able to do anything about it. While the government is saying it wants to try to move traffic out to Badgerys Creek, what is the good old FAC doing? It had plans leaked today. Of course, you cannot believe all that you read in the Sydney Morning Herald, but on some of these issues it has been right. If it is to be believed, the FAC has another plan to spend another $500 million at Sydney airport. This will make it absolutely impossible, when the Olympics come around, for anyone to sustain an argument that says, 'Do not do away with the curfew.' Some of the things that have been done in this business verge on the criminal. The effect it has had on the lives of the people in my electorate verges on the obscene. I think at least this will help them a bit. It is not going to help them much, but at least the minister has got to the stage where he is trying to do something for the people who are affected by the airport. Now we have the opposition saying, 'Isn't this terrible? The government should never have done it.' Crikey, this is the greatest case of amnesia I have witnessed in my life! My dear friend the member for Cowper( Mr Nehl), from the north coast of New South Wales, was in favour of this proposal because he wanted to do the best thing for his constituents. He wanted commuter airlines to be able to fly into Sydney airport. When he travels on Qantas next time, he ought to find out from James Strong what his plan is for the commuters from his electorate, because his plan is to get rid of them-they are a nuisance, so get rid of them. This whole scam has been run by the FAC for the two big airlines and a whole lot of other people have been sucked into it-some for good intentions, like country members, and others, like John Fahey and Nick Greiner, for their own political reasons. I think that everyone ought to very closely scrutinise anything that goes on at Sydney airport in the future, because the one thing to look back on is that what the member for Barton and I said is true. What we said would happen has happened. Everyone said at the time that we were misguided scaremongers. We were probably conservative, because it has turned out to be even worse than we thought. It was pretty hard to find anyone who thought worse than this for the last 10 years than the member for Barton and I. On that note I might finish. I commend the legislation to the House and I would suggest to all members that they very carefully scrutinise anything that goes on at Sydney airport. WhatI have said is not an attack on the minister, who I think has done more than anyone else to try to alleviate the suffering of the people around the airport, it is not even an attack on previous transport ministers on either side of the House, but it certainly is an attack on the Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1673 government's advisers. The FAC knew and it kept quiet, because it was an organisation that had been captured by its client group, the airline industry. honourable member for Watson( Mr Leo McLeay) with which I agree and which I will expand on in terms of the future of this particular piece of legislation. There are other aspects, of course, where he was right out. I categorically deny that I ever mentioned lifting a curfew on Sydney airport. I think the honourable member will find that that was a ploy that was leaked by a Labor Party operative who misquoted a letter that I once wrote to him regarding the future of aircraft noise. I was pointing out in that letter that aircraft were getting quieter and quieter and that by about the year 2025 we may not have conventional aircraft, as such, operating. That aside, the opposition is not going to oppose the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill 1995. I have a great deal of sympathy with what the member for Watson said in terms of some of the information that was given out regarding the effects of the opening of that third runway. This is but a very small way of trying to amend that particular situation. I want to give the honourable member for Watson some advice so that he can go in with his minister now and start getting things right for Badgerys Creek. There is absolutely nothing wrong with a major airport being on the edge of town, which Sydney West will be. The secret to the success of that particular airport will be the infrastructure, and the provision of fast and rapid transport to get in and out. Let us look at some of the major airports being developed now around the world. The Denver international airport, which opened a few months ago, is about 52 miles out of the city and it has plans for a high speed rail link. More importantly, I suggest that the honourable member for Watson have a look at Stansted Airport in the UK which is coming on stream as London's No.3 airport. It is interesting in that Stansted is an identical distance from the middle of London as Badgerys Creek is from the middle of Sydney. With the British Rail link that operates there, it is possible to get from Stansted to Liverpool Street Station, in the heart of London, in 42 minutes. Now, that is not a bad trip. Quite often, especially in the morning periods, it is almost impossible to get from Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport to the centre of the city in 42 minutes. The secret to it is that infrastructure: it has got to be high speed and it has probably got to be high speed rail. I was almost going to use an expression which would be politically unacceptable when saying that we can talk a lot about the development of Sydney West airport but, until such time as we get the infrastructure in place, we are not going to maximise the potential of that particular airport. There is no doubt that with the development of traffic coming into Australia, and into Sydney in particular, there will be a need for two airports. The reality is that about 62 per cent of the total air traffic in and out of Australia is going to use Sydney either for arrival or departure. With the expansion of airline services to Australia, and with things such as the Olympic Games coming up, there is no doubt that we will require those two facilities. It must be done properly this time so that, hopefully, we will never again see the situation that has developed in Sydney. This particular legislation is very much about Sydney airport. We heard the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport ( Mr O'Keefe) say in his second reading speech today that we have to have declared airports before these formulae for noise alleviation come into play. I would like to inform the government that there are a number of airports that will have
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Jull (Fadden) (2.11 P.m.)
theText: There are some aspects of the contribution made by theMC 1674 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 to be declared in a hurry. If we are to look at the noise problems around Australia, may I suggest that the officials responsible have a very quick look at the approach path to Coolangatta. I am sure the honourable member for McPherson( Mr Bradford) will be talking about that a little later. I would also like to expose what has been happening in terms of Brisbane airport. What the honourable member for Watson was saying about government advisers is really quite interesting. There has been quite a lobby group on the south side of Brisbane for many years now who complained about aircraft noise when the new international airport in Brisbane opened in 1988. Seven years later there are still problems. As we see in this bill, there is a specific formula for determining what constitutes a badly noise affected area that would then allow people and institutions to take advantage of the bill. The magic figure is 60 decibels which, in technical terms, applies to 25 ANEFs. This particular group in Brisbane has been advised by Dr R.V. Dubs, the general manager of planning and development in the Civil Aviation Authority, that, as far as it is concerned, it would appear that Brisbane does not have these problems and that there are not any areas in the flight paths that would qualify for this sort of assistance. The reality is that there have been a number of studies done on noise exposure distribution in Brisbane, and it is quite interesting when the facts come to light. I would like to quote, as a couple of examples, studies that were done in April and June of last year in two very badly affected areas-namely, around the Tingalpa school and also at Cannon Hill. I would want to place particular emphasis on Cannon Hill because it is proposed to develop the area there that once contained the Brisbane abattoir by building something like 12,000 new dwellings. The Queensland state government and the Brisbane City Council seem to be pretty anxious to have 12,000 new dwellings put on that particular space. But the interesting thing about that particular location at Cannon Hill is that a noise monitor has been put nearby. In a particular period, from April to June last year, some very interesting figures came through. During that period there were 3,037 aircraft movements in that region. Of these 3,037 aircraft movements, no fewer than 2,857 of them registered above the 70 decibel mark-between 70 and 90 decibels. If the Queensland government is going to proceed with that housing development of 12,000 new dwellings, somebody is going to have a problem in terms of providing the insulation and the noise reduction facilities there. About 61.5 per cent of the traffic at that time actually broke the legal limit and, of course, while that is referring particularly to that new development site, Cannon Hill is one of those areas which are badly affected by aircraft noise. The second study was done at the Tingalpa state school, and bear in mind the CAA says that there are no areas that actually qualify for any of this assistance under its formula. In that period, from April to June last year, at the Tingalpa state school there were 4,249 movements of which 2,447 were registered as being above 70 decibels, or 56.5 per cent of the total. At this stage, this legislation is designed strictly for Sydney, but the reality has to be faced that places such as the south side of Brisbane have some real problems. Of course, one of the reasons that the CAA says that there are no problems in Brisbane is that aeroplanes are supposed to follow their designated flight paths. The official CAA map is really quite interesting because it shows where those aircraft should go. In fact, there is a noise monitoring facility at Princess Street in Morningside and another one at Tingalpa. There are some on the north side. But it is true that it is not uncommon for aeroplanes approaching Thursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1675 Brisbane, especially from the north, to be two or three kilometres away from their designated flight paths. In the very area where I live it is quite interesting because the southerly flight path is a couple of kilometres away from my home and I have watched those aircraft approach. There is a flight path that comes in from New Zealand over the Redland Bay beacon and I can watch that. They are the designated flight paths, but an awful lot of aeroplanes fly straight over the top of our place. That does not particularly worry me. I quite enjoy it, actually. I set up my monitor and I listen to what is happening in the Brisbane tower. I can tell honourable members that a heck of a lot can be learned about the operation of the Civil Aviation Authority by monitoring some of those conversations. As I have said, in a personal sense, I have got no vested interest in this. But the reality is that these aeroplanes do stray from their official flight paths. In terms of that area on the south side of Brisbane-through Balmoral Heights and Cannon Hill and down through Tingalpa to the Seven Hills area-people have a real problem. The government has duckshoved this for a number of years, and has denied that there is a problem there. My estimate is that we will probably see nothing whatsoever done about it. I have mentioned Coolangatta, and there are other airports around Australia which have these problems. I hope some people are not going to get their hopes up too much when they read that this legislation is in play, because this legislation provides only for jet aircraft, yet there are many airports that receive incredible amounts of noise from non-jet aircraft. The people of Moorabbin and surrounding places are not going to get any benefit from this particular legislation. One could look at Archerfield, in Brisbane. Any member on the south side of Brisbane will talk about the phone calls he gets-at 4 o'clock in the morning, at home-from the residents of Salisbury or Oxley because the propeller driven freighters are going over at 4 o'clock in the morning and blasting everybody out of their beds. Those people are not going to get any relief from this particular legislation, because we are only covering jet aircraft. Like my colleague the honourable member for Hume( Mr Sharp), I get a bit cynical about this, because the passengers who are going to be hit more than anybody else are the poor devils flying on the BAe146, one of the 'quietest aircraft in the skies. Are honourable members aware that we are so good that Australia is the only country in the world that has any curfew on the BAe146 whatsoever? Australia is the only country in the world that has any restrictions on this. The BAe146 happily flies around freight services during all hours of the day and night in Europe, with no restrictions whatsoever. But we come in here and we slam every passenger on the BAe146 $5.17 per head, on average. I really wonder. I know there are supposed to be provisions here to ensure that there is going to be no major profit made by the authorities from this particular operation. But I really wonder why that BAe146 crept in here. In fact, I would have thought that they might have been given a bit more encouragement than, say, the Boeing 727, which is still operated by Ansett. When the honourable member for Watson. and J started talking about aircraft noise in Sydney, the real argument, to a very great extent, has been about the fact that the 727 is still operating over some of those areas. It is a very rowdy aircraft. The two aircraft that probably cause more concern than most-they certainly do on the south side of Brisbane-are the Fokker F28 and the Boeing 727, which are old aircraft. The F28, apparently,. is going out of service. Ansett was suggesting that we were going to see the demise MC 1676 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 of the 727 from its fleet late last year. There are now suggestions that the 727 could be flying well into the next century. Unless they are hush-kitted, we are going to have some enormous problems there. But the fact that the BAe146 has got the big slam really makes me quite amused. The real worry is that this particular legislation is not going to cover a number of other people around Australia who have some real difficulties in terms of aircraft noise. I would hope that the government would prove to be quite genuine in providing for the people of Sydney, who have got their own specific problems, and genuine in terms of the people who live in the flight path of the Coolangatta airport or on the south side of Brisbane. I hope the government will be genuine for the people at Archerfield, Moorabbin or Bankstown, and make sure that all those who are badly affected by aircraft noise do get some sort of compensation. Most importantly, let us hope that there is some honesty, and that the officials who are responsible for these things do not try to ducks hove some of the noise readings and some of the formulas that they use. Let us make sure they get out there amongst the real people who are experiencing these noises. Let us make sure they put their monitoring services underneath the actual flight paths instead of the theoretical flight paths, and let us try to get some justice for the great number of people who are being very deeply affected by aircraft noise. impose a levy on the landing of jet aircraft at certain airports. At the moment, this policy is directed at Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport. The purpose of this levy is to attempt to introduce some financially based discipline on the use of Sydney Kingsford Smith airport. Currently, the residents of the inner city and certain northern suburbs of Sydney are sorely punished by the operations of this airport. The opening of the third runway has not proved to be an improvement. The situation is now worse and residents of my electorate and those of Sydney, Grayndler and Bennelong demand that this parliament do something definite to ameliorate their suffering. Hopefully, this levy will go some way towards controlling the noise and take-off pattern of jet aircraft into and out of KSA. There are two bills to deal with on this matter-the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill 1995-and I will consider these together. In connection with these bills, I would also like to comment on the woeful situation that has brought about the requirement for this levy. Given the financial commitment, both public and private, and the current standards of the infrastructure at Sydney airport, it is patently obvious that this facility will remain in operation for many years to come. I think that the calls to close Sydney airport at this stage are wide of the mark. It is also clear, given the above premise, that airctaft operations will affect a substantial number of Sydney residents and these residents require, on health and public amenity grounds, the insulation of premises, reduction of engine noise and rigorous control of the flight paths. In reducing the rate of growth at Sydney airport, the government has no option but to press ahead with a second airport at Sydney West. Our tourism industry cannot be curtailed. It is our biggest export earner and the Sydney Olympics is staring us in the face. Knowing this, the government has committed substantial funds to the new airport. The May 1995 federal budget contained a commitment to provide $610 million additional funding for the accelerated development of Sydney West· airport by 1999. This budget allocation means a total funding commitment by the government of $762 million for the site development and -infrastructure.

speaker: Mrs Easson (Lowe) (2.25 P.m.)
theText: The Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 is for an act toThursday, 8 June 1995 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 1677 This is excellent news but, again, I emphasise that, as of today, no concrete has been poured so, although Sydney West airport will provide some solace in the years ahead to my constituents, what about the immediate future of the next four years? As for the suffering of residents due to the current operation of Sydney airport, I do acknowledge the decision of the federal government to approve $183.4 million over the next 10 years aimed at reducing the impact of aircraft noise on residents living around Sydney airport. This program was announced as costing $183.4 million in November 1994, as estimated by the FAC consultants. Following the extension of the coverage of the program and more detailed costings, the estimated costs have now increased by $76.6 million to $260 million. The major reasons for the increase in these costs estimated by the FAC consultants are: additional buildings identified for treatment within the previously announced categories and assistant areas; outcome of more detailed assessment of work required, particularly for air-conditioning, structural reinforcement and electrical work in schools and colleges; an upward movement in external noise levels to more clearly reflect the actual measured aircraft noise and resultant upwards adjustment in the level of sound treatment required; cost estimates for preliminary design documentation; and the project management not included in the earlier estimates. The government announced the immediate commencement of the schools installation program with completion targeted for the end of the first term of this year but the state, Catholic and other school administrations have subsequently expressed a preference for a staged approach to noise treatment so that the schools experience minimum disruption to educational activities. The eligible schools in my electorate of Lowe are Drummoyne public school and St Marks Catholic school in Drummoyne. Child-care facilities will also eventually be eligible. These will include Drummoyne Occasional Child Care Centre, College Street Child Care Centre, Drummoyne municipal preschool and Drummoyne Baptist preschool. The following churches and other places of worship will also eventually be eligible: Drummoyne Baptist Church, Drummoyne Presbyterian Church, St Marks Catholic Church and Drummoyne Uniting Church. The noise amelioration measures are useful and timely and I think that much attention must be given to this question of noise as it is a major health question. The bills before us today are stated to be for the purpose of financing this noise amelioration. The financial impact statement contained in the general outline of the bills says: The rate of levy to be prescribed under the legislation will be designed to recover the costs associated with noise amelioration works currently under way in Sydney, with a target collection rate of $32.2 million in the 1995/96 financial year. I hope that this is true. My electors and the residents of Sydney would be very disappointed and angry if moneys raised by these bills were to disappear into consolidated revenue. I am not very happy to have to call into question the honesty of public officials. However, the saga of this airport and the third runway and all the associated matters have brought about a situation where a lot of Sydney residents simply do not believe the word of any official associated with this matter. This is a sad situation, but the facts of the matter do give grounds for deep suspicion. We must ensure that these bills do not end up increasing the duplicity surrounding this matter. BeforeI go on speaking on the various clauses of the bill, I want to put on the record the serious health and social issues associated with noise. Aircraft noise above a certain level is a public health risk and, since the opening of the third runway, the New South Wales health department has been collecting data on the use of medical resources by residents affected by MC 1678 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 8 June 1995 the aircraft noise.:Morethan 70,000 people in Sydney now live withip the high noise contour area. Overseas studies have conclusively shown that aircraft noise is a serious cause of illness and the noise raises the stress level for' the very young and the very old. Medical investigations in Sydney show that areas affected by high aircraft noise have a highyr degree of arteriosclerosis, nephritis and nephrosis, and heart disease. Local general practitioners report a serious rise in insomnia, anxiety, high blood pressure and nerve ailments. The government's preferred option indealing with this problemis embodied in these biils. Frankly, I doubt whether firid will work effectively. I strongly suspect that the new community consultative committee, established by the Minister for Transport ( Mr Brereton) and chaired by Joe Riordan, will have to work very hard to monitor these prosecutions carefully, as well as the respective fines. These bills levy a payment on some jet aircraft landing at some prescribed airports. At the moment, it covers Sydney airport, but it is to be expanded with ministerial approval. The levy will represent approximately $3.40 per passenger in a jet aircraft at Sydney airport and it is intended that the levy rate will be adjusted in line with consumer price index movements. The aim will be to recover the costs associated with the program over a period of not more than 10 years. Clauses5 and 6 detail the method of calculation of the levy and stipulate that the levy shall be the same at all airports where a levy is charged. Because of the complexities of aircraft ownership-leaseholds, rentings, borrowings and all the other legal words surrounding possession and use-clause 4 of the levy collection bill boasts that it has a comprehensive definition of operator and thus identifies the person who must pay the levy. Clause6 of part 2 tells us about identifying those airports that qualify for the levy. Subclause (6) identifies the concept of ANEF. The ANEF system of noise measurement appears to be a questionable and easily manipulated one. It operates only in Australia and has been used extensively by the Civil Aviation Authority over the years. The CAA is now to be abolished by the government. Clause8 in part 3 leaves the question of actually paying the levy to be settled by regulation. I would suggest that the government not delay in issuing these regulations. I know that bureaucracy is large and deliberate and that it is invariably bad to rush things. However, I would again urge the bureaucracy and the ministry to be aware that the general public in Sydney is extremely distrustful of government in this area of civil aviation. This is a bad situation and my desire is to see the government adopt policies and regulations that actually address the aviation problems and help restore that level of trust and confidence that must exist between the people and their government. . Part4 of the levy collection bill deals with the power to gather information relevant to collecting the levy. This legislation is needed; I hope that it works. I have pointed out a few problems and perhaps I am wrong, but the bottom line is that swift and sure remedial action is needed to solve the noise problem at Sydney Kingsford Smith airport and to rapidly advance the construction of Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek.
